TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State', and
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; believing that its implemention would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as discribed in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3, Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 271 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school 'community' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 126 citizens), Bjelke-Petersen (from 60 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 365 citizens), Chaney (from 161 citizens) and Crichton-Browne (from 315 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BAUME; BOSWELL; CARRICK; HILL; LEWIS; MESSNER
PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Peter Baume (from 12 citizens), Boswell (from 75 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 15 citizens), Hill (from 13 citizens), Lewis (from 40 citizens) and Messner (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Lump Sum Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the Government's announced proposal to tax lump sum superannuation payments by up to 30 per cent is an unwarranted and unfair attack on the savings of Australians of average means and
Whereas the development of our nation requires the application of large sums of capital which can only be generated locally by the savings of Australians and
Whereas Government policies preventing the development of local capital only serve to increase Australia's dependence on foreign capital and
Whereas the encouragement of thrift and self-help should be paramount in our society,
We humbly pray that the Government will not proceed to impose a tax on lump sum superannuation payments above that presently existing.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Peter Baume (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry by banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 639 citizens) and Button (from 35 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the President and honourable Senators in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that we deplore the continuing presence of United States bases on Australian territory.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government urgently takes action to close all such bases.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commemorative Postage Stamps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That to this date no postage stamps have been issued to commemorate the services of the Australian Military Forces in the Occupation of Japan, Korea, Malaya, Malay Peninsular, Sabah, Sarawak and Vietnam.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should seek and support the issue of such commemorative stamps.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Government School Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, being parents and other persons concerned about the education of all children, showeth that the present Government has commenced a Policy of reduction and eventual abolition in Government funding to Independent Schools. This Policy has been adopted without an appropriate and reasoned consideration of the circumstances of those Schools and the parents who choose to send their children to them. In particular the Government, in making its decision, has failed to take into account the impact on the State School System of an increased enrolment of students who otherwise would have attended Independent Schools in the event that Government funding had not been reduced or abolished. The change in Policy overlooks the fact that the cost of educating a child in a Government School is two to three times the cost to the tax-payer of educating the same child in an Independent School.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled reverse the decision of the Government and re-instate funding on an equitable basis as has been the case in previous years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programmes and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robertson (from 64 citizens) and Zakharov (from 16 citizens).

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON VOLATILE SUBSTANCE FUMES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Volatile Substance Fumes, be appointed to inquire into and report upon the voluntary inhalation of volatile substance fumes, which particular reference to the health and social consequences of the availability of such substances to the community, particularly,-
(a) to persons who have not attained the age of 18 years; and
(b) where the practice of petrol sniffing has become endemic.
Provisions relating to the membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee are contained in paragraphs 2 to 13 of this motion. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(2) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows-
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee shall be three members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to the Senate by 5 June 1984.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may send its report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is not available, to the Deputy-President, who is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation and, in such event, the President or Deputy-President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Why did the Commonwealth Government fail to consult the Government of the Northern Territory about its intention to transfer the title of Uluru National Park to an Aboriginal land trust? Why was the formal advice of the decision telexed to Darwin too late for the Government there to be advised, prior to the Prime Minister's public announcement and after the Leader of the Opposition had been informed? How does he justify this high-handed treatment of the Northern Territory and its Government?

—I am not sure that the purported facts in the Leader of the Opposition's question are correct, but I will address the question to the Prime Minister and obtain an answer, if possible, by the end of Question Time.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to the Federal Government's proposal for a national occupational health and safety commission. Firstly, can the Minister say whether the commission is likely to contain a preventative health component in its charter? Secondly, will the commission be laying down the rights and obligations of employees, employers and governments?

—As I understand it, an announcement will be made shortly in relation to this matter by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In answer to the specifics of the honourable senator's question, let me say first of all that I understand that the commission will contain a preventative health component. In regard to the question of laying down the rights and obligations of employers and employees, I think that is a matter with which the commission will not be concerned. It is a matter which has been dealt with or is in the process of being dealt with in various State considerations of the same problem; namely, industrial health and occupational safety. That is a matter which is appropriately within the jurisdiction of the States and is not a matter with which the Federal commission would be primarily concerned. I am unable to say with definition at this stage whether there will be some provision relating to that matter.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, concerns the protest being staged against the joint Australian-United States defence facility at Pine Gap. Is the Minister aware that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, was one of 12 women Labor members of parliament who issued a statement last week expressing support for the Pine Gap protesters? Does he recall a recent answer in the Senate from Senator Gareth Evans, on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in which he quoted Mr Hayden who, in a statement on the ANZUS treaty, endorsed the presence in Australia of facilities such as Pine Gap because of their contribution to the deterrence of nuclear war? Does the Minister believe that it is proper for a Minister to support publicly people who are demonstrating to reverse a policy endorsed by Mr Hayden?

—I am aware of the Pine Gap protest and I understand that a number of Labor members of parliament sent a message to the protesters in support of the general concern being expressed by those protesters in terms of nuclear weapons, et cetera. My understanding is that Senator Ryan was one of the signatories to that message but I also understand that she specifically distinguished any comment she made about the protest in terms of the role and function of the base at Pine Gap and the Government's policy in relation to the role and function of that base. If Senator Kilgariff can construe the message that I saw in the terms which he suggests in his question, namely, that it supported total opposition to the Pine Gap base contrary to Government policy, I certainly did not read it that way.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I have received a number of submissions from women and men in Alice Springs regarding the brutality in the treatment of women arrested at Pine Gap and of other possible breaches of human rights in the course of their arrest and detention. I understand that the Attorney-General has been involved in similar discussions. I ask: What action has he taken and has he any further proposals? In particular, is any consideration being given to the possibility of the Human Rights Commission sending an observer to Alice Springs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was first made aware of these complaints on Sunday evening around midnight when I received a telephone call from Mrs Joan Coxsedge, MLC. I hasten to add that that is not a normal state of affairs. I have subsequently received several direct representations from or on behalf of women who have been arrested and I have, of course, seen the allegations that have been made in Press reports. The action I have taken is as follows: In response to Mrs Coxsedge's call, I telephoned shortly afterwards the officer in charge of the Alice Springs police station. I put to him a series of specific questions and received responses along the following lines: That the women were being charged with trespass under the Commonwealth Crimes Act and not under the legislation specifically relating to defence installations such as Pine Gap, in other words with a comparatively minor offence; that bail processing was proceeding as fast as possible with the exception that it was not possible to process either those who did not want bail or those who refused to give a correct name; that there was no question of denying the women access to lawyers and that lawyers were being allowed in to talk to anyone who requested a lawyer; and that there were no particular crowding problems as the cells were built for more than 100 people. There had been some difficulties with plumbing and matters of that kind but by that stage those had been resolved. That is where the matter rested on Sunday night.

ANSWER.PARA: Requests were subsequently made to me and also to the Human Rights Commission that a human rights observer be sent to Alice Springs to monitor the proper observance of human rights standards in police and legal dealings with the women . I have now been advised, just a short time ago, that the Human Rights Commission-not in fact acting at my request but of its own volition-at a meeting convened this morning in Melbourne decided to send one of its officers to Alice Springs to inquire into the complaints and to identify any breaches of human rights that may have occurred. In the light of that, I have asked the Commission to provide me with a report as soon as possible.

As to the behaviour of the police, I emphasise that the arrests and detention have been carried out by Northern Territory police, as I understand it, and not by Federal police, although the Northern Territory police have been acting under Commonwealth law. Questions of police behaviour and allegations of brutality-in respect of which I hasten to add that I have received no hard evidence of any inappropriate or excessive use of police power although such claims have been made-are, of course, primarily matters for the responsible Northern Territory Minister, in this case the Chief Minister, Mr Everingham. I note from this morning's Age report that a Northern Territory police spokesman said that there would be an investigation if there were any indication that injuries had been suffered by anyone in custody. I welcome that assurance and I hope that it also extends to an investigation of complaints that are made by people in custody.

I mention that concern has been expressed about the availability of legal aid and I advise the Senate that in anticipation of difficulties such as have arisen the Australian Legal Aid Office in Darwin-again not acting with any Government direction but of its own initiative-did make special arrangements for a legal aid officer in Alice Springs to be available full time as a duty solicitor to provide urgent legal advice and representation. For those who pleaded not guilty and whose cases have, therefore, been adjourned, applications for legal aid will be processed in the usual way, with due attention being given to the merits of individual cases and the ability of applicants to pay. It is usually possible for applicants who are approved for legal aid to have the lawyer of their choice , but this may not, of course, be very practicable in a remote spot like Alice Springs.

In conclusion, the action that I, the Government and various government agencies have taken should not be taken as implying, in turn, any support for the tactics employed by the demonstrators in question and, in particular, for the tactic of forcible entry. What our action does do is, I think, demonstrate very clearly our concern that basic human rights should be enjoyed by all members of the community however popular or unpopular may be the particular causes they are espousing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs may recall a question which I asked him on 15 September and to which he replied that the Government was not aware that the Soviets had adopted a policy of launching on warning their nuclear arsenals on the basis of a computer warning because of the deployment of the Pershing missiles. I ask the Minister whether he has seen a article in the Weekend Australian which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Soviet military sources have hinted recently that a policy of 'automatic launching' of Soviet missiles was under consideration as a response to the new US nuclear missiles.

Is the Government aware that a Soviet newspaper and officials visiting West Germany have mentioned that 'launch on warning' was an option for the Soviets in retaliation? Does the Government not consider that the deployment of the Cruise and Pershing II missiles, being for political rather than military reasons, and forcing the serious consideration of a launch on warning policy by the Soviets, will be a destabilising, counter-productive policy that should be halted and reversed immediately? Is the Australian Government taking any action designed to bring about such a change?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report to which Senator Chipp refers. It is , of course, the case that there is considerable debate in Europe at the moment on every aspect of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation intermediate- range nuclear force modernisation program. The article to which the honourable senator refers has to be seen in that context. The only response that I have been able to elicit from the Minister so far, in anticipation of this kind of question, is that we would not have expected the Soviet Union to make public its plans for the possible use of nuclear weapons or, for that matter, to be particularly likely to use Soviet journalists as official spokesmen in that respect.
—It often does.

—I appreciate that. The point has just been taken that, given the magnitude of the matters in issue here, it is a somewhat implausible route for such publicity to be given. But, given the gravity of the matters with which Senator Chipp's question is concerned, I will of course refer the matter to the Minister and seek a more detailed response to it.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to comments reported today in which it is suggested that 'as far as minerals are concerned, the present farrago of Commonwealth and State taxes, charges, levies, royalties and fees is hardly rational'? Can the Minister say whether this is a correct description of the situation? If so, what steps are he and the present Government taking to try to have a more rational resources taxation policy implemented?

—If I remember correctly, the words Senator Coates has quoted were used by Senator Chaney yesterday; that is, that as far as minerals are concerned , the present farrago of Commonwealth and State taxes, charges, levies, royalties and fees is hardly rational. I certainly agree with that statement. The problem appears to be, if Senator Chaney was accurately reported, that, having made that statement, he then proceeded to reject the rational alternative which this Government has proposed. I have not had an opportunity to read his complete speech, but from the reports of it that was the tone of it. I am disappointed by that. I have noted a couple of other things, though, which Senator Chaney is reported to have said, one of which is that the Government's whole approach to a resources rent tax has been masked in the language of economic rationality. I am not sure of the context in which that appeared, but it would appear to be implicitly critical of economic rationality. I would be interested to know why the Opposition is critical of economic rationality. Indeed, I suggest that it should try it some time instead of the mixture of redneck economics and political opportunism which it practised in government and which is responsible for its being where it is now-that is, in opposition.

—Does the Minister for Industry and Commerce recall his reply to me, during the debate on the Appropriation Bills on 2 November, that he had not obtained responses from the New South Wales and South Australian governments concerning their contributions to the steel industry plan but that he expected that a submission would be put to the New South Wales Cabinet shortly? Following reports of the Minister having rapped the New South Wales Government yesterday at Port Kembla, has the Minister seen the comment attributed to a spokesman for the State Minister claiming that further information will be on its way shortly, whilst another said that such concessions are something 'we are prepared to look at without being able to give an indication at this stage of how soon a decision might be made'? What action will the Minister now take to attempt to induce a more energetic approach from the Wran Government to remove this aura of uncertainty which is hanging over the prospects of the steel industry package?

—To dignify this matter with the description of 'an aura of uncertainty' is, to say the least, indulging in hyperbole. The fact of the matter is that at no stage of the development of the steel package, as it has been described by Senator Rae, was a significant contribution sought from the New South Wales Government or the South Australian Government. But in answer to the substantive part of the honourable senator's question let me say that yesterday I received a letter from the New South Wales Minister responsible for industrial affairs informing me that he hoped to be able to provide me with an answer to the Commonwealth Government's request by the end of this month. That is the position as I now understand it.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to an article in the Tasmanian Press concerning a newsletter circulated by the Principal of Dominic College in Hobart, Father John Papworth, expressing his concern about the Labor Government's policy of funding schools on a needs basis instead of tying grants to a percentage of the cost of educating a student at a government school? Did Father Papworth say, amongst other things: ' If the trend continues'-that is the trend in Labor policy-'we will be forced to put up fees, which will be a cause of a great deal of concern to parents'? I ask : What would Dominic College have received from the Commonwealth under the previous Government's funding policy? What will Dominic College receive in the first year of the new Government's funding policy? Will it be left entirely to Labor policy to determine the actual needs of schools, as Father Papworth implies? In general, are any Tasmanian non-government schools to receive less in real terms under Labor Government guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to this matter and I must repeat that it is extremely disappointing when administrators of schools, who are of course in full possession of the information about the effects of the Government's new funding policies, make statements or make inferences which are quite inaccurate and quite misleading and no doubt cause great concern to the parents who receive these things. Dominic College, which is referred to in Senator Tate's question, is a non-systemic school in group 3. Had the previous Government's funding policy continued Dominic College would have received $739 for each primary student and $1,156 for each secondary student in 1984. As a result of our policies Dominic College will receive more than this: It will receive $741 for each primary student and $1,171 for each secondary student in 1984. That is a $2 increase for each primary student and a $15 increase for each secondary student. What this means in total is that, under Labor, Dominic College will receive some $15,063 more than it would have received had the previous Government's funding policy continued. I hope that the principal of the school will inform the parents of that fact. I hope that he will explain to them, if he decides to put up fees, why he needs to put up fees in the light of the considerable increase in recurrent funds that he has received from the Commonwealth under our funding policy.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to determination of a community standard for schools and a needs- based policy, I reiterate that it is the policy of this Government to fund according to needs. The Schools Commission will provide the Government with advice on the community standard. That advice will be provided after the Schools Commission has consulted widely with all non-government school bodies in all States and Territories in Australia. A first step in this consultative process has been taken already with the release by the Schools Commission last week of a document entitled 'Target Recurrent Resource Standards'. That document has been released for discussion and public comment. I look forward to receiving informed public comment on it. I conclude by saying that no non-government school in Tasmania will receive less funding in real terms in 1984 than it did in 1983 and the vast majority will receive more.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Following the last question, I ask her whether it is a fact that, under the previous Government's policy, Dominic College and like schools had a guarantee of a fixed percentage of the cost of educating a State school child. Is it a fact that her Government and she, as Minister, have removed that guarantee this year and for the future?

—It is a fact that under the previous Government's policy Dominic College and other non-government schools were guaranteed a percentage of average government school costs but, of course, that guarantee meant that if increases in average government school costs were low-increases in costs, of course, are not going to be as rapid as they have been because of our Government's successful reduction of inflation and our wages and prices policy-although there would be some increase guaranteed, the amount of that increase could never have been subject to guarantee. All it meant was that Dominic College, a level three school, would have got the same percentage of whatever the increase was as schools with much more resources. In contrast, what Dominic College and all schools in similar positions have under our Government is a guarantee that they will receive more funding and that they will progress more quickly to a level where they have completely adequate resource standards to provide a high quality education to all of their children. They will proceed much faster to that level than they could have proceeded under the previous formula. Of course, under the previous formula there was no mechanism for closing the gaps between the very high resource schools and schools which are struggling.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. I welcome the use of the word 'guarantee' by the Minister in her answer. I ask her to confirm that she is guaranteeing that Dominic College and other level three schools will receive more under this Government than they would have received under the guarantee that previously applied.

—If Senator Chaney had addressed himself to the answer that I gave to Senator Tate, he would have heard the specific amounts of money which Dominic College will receive in 1984. In 1984 Dominic College will receive $15,063 more by way of recurrent grants than it received under the formula of the Government of which Senator Chaney was a member.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the Minister satisfied that staff resources in the Darwin office of his Department are adequate for the needs of the Northern Territory's ex-Services community? If not, what action is he considering to improve the service?

—The Government has become increasingly concerned about information which shows that veterans are not aware of the benefits and facilities available to them from the Government. Consequently, it is extending its services to more centres and regional areas throughout Australia, and it has done that in recent months. I recall that Senator Robertson asked me privately several weeks ago about the Darwin office of the Department of Veterans' Affairs , which is run jointly as an office of the Department and of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service in Darwin. That was opened about 18 months ago, in May 1982, with a staff of two. Following Senator Robertson's inquiry, I instigated an examination of the officers' work loads. There is no doubt that the present facilities are inadequate, and I have decided that existing staff resources will be increased by an additional person, a full time clerical assistant, so that the inquiries being made by ex-servicemen in the Northern Territory can be properly attended to. I have also instructed my Department to keep the service under regular review so that if the increasing demand is still not being met by adequate staff arrangements we can increase the staff still further.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of conflicting media reports, can he say whether the Government has made a decision concerning the declaration of Stage II of the Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory? Is he aware of the widespread concern that any such decision in advance of a proper survey of the potential of this vast area will permanently lock away resources which could produce billions of dollars of income for all Australians? If it is not yet too late, will the Government take the advice of the Northern Territory Government to excise the Jabiluka uranium deposit from Stage II, declare only half of the second stage, and impose a conservation zone on the remainder, or will the Federal Government again ignore the wishes of that Government in an effort to square off with sections of the Labor Party enraged by the Caucus decision on uranium mining?
—Mr President--
—Wait until after the election, he says.

—I was not going to say that, but I am indebted to Senator Withers for the suggestion. An announcement will be made about Stage II of the Kakadu National Park at an appropriate time. However, there has been widespread newspaper speculation about the Government's decision on this matter.
—Speculation by the Minister, Mr Cohen.

—Senator Chaney suggests that there has been speculation by the Minister, Mr Cohen. As I said, an announcement will be made at the appropriate time. As to the position regarding Jabiluka and Koongarra, it is my understanding that they will be treated separately from the decision in relation to Kakadu Stage II because of certain legal arrangements which have to be entered into with the Northern Territory Government and the traditional landholders. I am unable to advance any further information on that at this stage.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the decision, when it is made, be made as a result of in-depth and careful deliberation, consideration and consultation with the Government of the Northern Territory?
—Order! I regard that as not being a supplementary question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES AIR FORCE: B52G AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is reported that the United States Air Force has upgraded its strategic bomber force in the Pacific by replacing the 14 B52D aircraft stationed at Guam with the B52G aircraft, each capable of carrying 20 short-range Cruise missiles equipped with a nuclear warhead of the size of that carried by a Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missile, as well as the usual full bomb load. Are these B52G aircraft flying over Australian territory and using bases in this country? Are the missiles being unloaded before these aircraft fly over our land?

—Regrettably, the brief I had on this matter seems to have been mislaid. I assure the honourable senator and the Senate that there is nothing sinister whatsoever to be derived from that state of affairs. I will seek an early and appropriate answer for the honourable senator.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has Cabinet considered the question of compensation for miners and Aboriginals adversely affected by the Government's uranium decision last week? What amount has been claimed so far? What was the Government's estimate of amounts which would be claimed by the Northern Territory, the miners and the Aboriginals?

—Cabinet has considered a number of issues relating to mining in the Northern Territory. Insofar as the question of compensation is concerned, if that question arises the Government will make an announcement at the appropriate time. I was asked, secondly, whether an amount of compensation has been assessed . The answer to that question is no; that is, assuming it to be a relevant question for the purposes of giving it an answer. In relation to any estimate of the amount which might be claimed, as Senator Walters put it in her question, by the Northern Territory Government on behalf of miners and traditional land owners, I do not think anybody in his wildest imagination could give an estimate here of the amount which might be claimed by the Northern Territory Government. If the Northern Territory does make such a claim, it will be rejected. If it made such a claim in a court, it would also be rejected.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister telling us that when the decision on uranium was taken by Caucus, no account was taken of what the taxpayer and the Government could be up for in compensation? If not, I cannot imagine on what basis it could possibly have come to its decision.

—I am surprised that Senator Walters cannot imagine that; she can imagine everything else that comes into the deliberations in this place. No, I did not say that no account was taken of these issues, or that no account will be taken of them. But when the Government is in a position, having assessed all the facts, and not imagined them, to make a statement about this matter, it will do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It follows from a speech made in the Senate by my colleague Senator Reynolds. Is the Minister aware of a recent report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Nationwide on the plight of Aboriginal employees at Queensland's Cape Flattery silica mine? It was reported that Aboriginal workers at the mine were on strike, not for extra pay or better conditions, but against the use of racist practices by the management of the mine. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has investigated the allegations that discriminatory practices are in operation at the mine, and whether the dispute has satisfactorily been resolved? Can the workers, who were previously barred from joining a union, now join a union? Further, is the Government considering establishing mechanisms to monitor the health and safety conditions at the mine where the dangers of silicosis and other diseases related to handling of the fine silica dust are prevalent?

—My colleague Mr Holding has provided me with a brief on the matter raised by Senator Richardson's question. His attention had been drawn to a recent report on Nationwide, although he did not view it. He understood that the program covered the matter mentioned by the honourable senator; that is, the Aboriginal workers at Cape Flattery went on strike on account of alleged discriminatory practices at the mine. The terms on which the workers returned to the mine are known to my colleague's Department and I shall see that the details are provided to the honourable senator. On access to union membership, I am informed that the Australian Workers Union is endeavouring to arrange discussions on the matter with the workers. With regard to the health and safety situation at the mine, I am informed that my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has already been in touch with the appropriate Queensland Minister and is awaiting a reply.

—Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that the foreign affairs and defence committee of the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party passed a motion on Sunday claiming that the Caucus decision on uranium has no standing? Is he further aware that this motion will be put before a special State conference on uranium to be held on the twenty-seventh of this month and that a prominent Labor Party member, Mr Bill Hartley, believes it will be accepted by that meeting? Does Senator Button agree with that part of the motion which claims that Caucus exceeded its powers in interpreting the Party platform on uranium? If the motion is passed, what effect will it have on the Government's uranium decision of last week?

—I try to keep abreast of all the important events which take place in this country but I was not aware of the decision of the foreign affairs and defence committee of the Victorian branch of the Labor Party. I take Senator Hamer's word for it that such a decision was made in relation to the Caucus decision of a little over a week ago. Of course it is common knowledge that there is a difference of opinion within the Australian Labor Party about the platform in relation to uranium mining which was arrived at at the 1982 conference of the Party. I am quite aware that that matter will be debated at a conference of the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party, I think on 27 November, as Senator Hamer again informed me. I believe I will have the dubious honour of attending that conference and I look forward to that. As to the suggestion that Caucus might have exceeded its powers, that is an interpretation with which I do not agree. I made that clear in answers to questions in this chamber last week.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: STAFF TAX DEDUCTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. How many Australian high commissioners receive their salaries without pay as you earn tax deductions? How many other Department of Foreign Affairs staff receive their salaries without PAYE tax deductions? If any, has approval been given to each of these cases by the Australian Commissioner of Taxation and what was the date of each such approval?

—Mr President, Senator Primmer should be well aware that matters of this kind are matters between-I was going to say the taxpayers and their makers-but certainly between the taxpayers and the Commissioner of Taxation, who does not occupy quite such an exalted position. Answers to similar questions in the past, when retailed to the Commissioner of Taxation, have invariably elicited the response that no such information will be forthcoming as to the individual taxpayer's arrangements. I imagine that a similar response can be anticipated in this instance, but to the extent that there is anything which can be put on the public record consistent with that tradition I will refer the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Sentor ARCHER-My question is directed to the Attorney-General. With the increasing lawlessness being exhibited by disruptionist and subversive groups in recent demonstrations around Australia, can the Attorney advise what action the Government has decided to take and/or what legislation it has decided to introduce as would be appropriate to safeguard the progress, development and security of the nation?

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is any necessity for legislation in this country in the areas to which Senator Archer refers, it is undoubtedly to counter some of the very extravagant human rights invading legislation generated by generations, in turn, of conservative governments that have been profoundly indifferent to the basic human rights of freedom of speech and freedom of protest. Of course there must be a legitimate regulatory framework within which that protest can occur. It is all too much to be regretted that in many parts of Australia there has been a profound indifference to the necessity to balance that regulatory framework with appropriate protections for the rights of the individuals concerned. I have no intention whatsoever of embarking on the kinds of adventures that Senator Archer encourages me to. I believe that, to the extent that a law-making job needs to be done, it is one that needs to operate wholly in the contrary direction.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, relates to the announcement by the Victorian Government that it is to drop all financial aid to the Australian Ballet and the Australian Opera for their 1984 seasons and to cut its grant to the Australian Dance Theatre from $260,000 to $130,000 during the coming year. In the light of this sudden and drastic action by the Cain Labor Government and the longstanding poor deal which opera subscribers have received in Victoria, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what steps will be taken by the Federal Government to offset the severe financial problems that these cuts will place upon planned performances by the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Australian Dance Theatre within Victoria; and, secondly, will he assure the Senate that the Commonwealth Government will act promptly to ensure that the citizens of Victoria are not denied access to the high quality performances currently offered by these groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to refer the detailed matter of the honourable senator' s question concerning the Victorian Government's reduction of funds for the Australian Opera to my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen. I point out to Senator Missen, as he has requested direct Federal Government action in this matter, both with regard to the particular company that has had its funding reduced by a State government decision and in general in terms of access by Victorians to the performances of this company, that it appears to be the view of his Party-indeed it is of ours-that funding decisions of the Australia Council should be independent and should be made without political interference. Indeed, during the consideration of the Estimates by the Committee of the Whole in this chamber last week, I was treated to quite a lecture from Senator Martin to the effect that all decisions concerning funding of performing arts companies throughout Australia should be decisions made independently by the boards of the Australia Council and by the Australia Council and that even any suggestion by a Minister of overall policy objectives of the Australia Council was something that she at least questioned.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of that, and given that I agree with Senator Martin and with the Liberal Party that decisions about the funding of individual companies are decisions for the Australia Council to make, I very much doubt that there will be direct Federal Government action with regard to this company. However, I point out that because our Government believes in the independence of the Australia Council we have transferred the decision-making power of this company concerning opera and ballet from what it was under the Fraser Government-that is , a Cabinet decision-to the Australia Council. The Australia Council, of course, has much more funding at its disposal to assist companies such as the Victorian opera company. I can only express the hope, if Senator Martin will not regard this as a dreadful interference in the business of the Australia Council, that decisions are made by the Australia Council so that the Victorians are not denied access to the benefits of such performances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from the answer that the Minister regards a decision to increase the amount of funding to overcome a deficiency caused by a State government as an interference with those particular bodies?

—I am suggesting that that interpretation may well be put on it by other members of the Opposition, although obviously not by Senator Missen. What I am saying is that any decision taken to increase Federal funding to that company to help it overcome the problems of suffering a loss in its State grant will be a decision of the Australia Council, but I will convey the honourable senator's concerns to the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. The Government's new first home owners scheme has been operating now for six weeks. Can the Minister state what impact it is having on the housing industry, particularly in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for the question. I will seek to answer it for him. Mr President, as you know, when this Government came to office in March it was confronted with a situation in which the housing industry was operating well below capacity, in fact, at a record low capacity. For various reasons, many potential home buyers were unable to afford the interest rates being charged on housing loans and could not enter into home purchase. One of the first actions the Government took was to review the housing policies and the programs which were in place at that time. As a result of that review we introduced a number of specific measures not only to aid the housing industry but also to generate jobs and to assist those wishing to obtain their first home .

ANSWER.PARA: A key to this package, as Senator Foreman has said, which was first announced in the May economic statement, is the first home owners scheme which commenced on 1 October last. In the first six weeks of operation over 10,000 applications were received. Senator Foreman may be interested to know that 1,000 applications have been received in South Australia. As well as the 10,000 or so applications there have been over 140,000 inquiries and Department of Housing and Construction offices are being inundated by requests for application forms. The new first home owners scheme was designed to assist low and moderate income earners not only to obtain extra housing finance but also to reduce the repayment burden. The Government also took action to look after those who are unable to afford housing in the private market. We provided $500m for public housing compared with the $330m which was provided by the previous Government. South Australia received about $62m of this amount. Apart from these well targeted and efficient programs, the most effective action the Government has taken to assist home owners and the housing industry has been to create the environment for a reduction in interest rates. Since last December interest rates have fallen by between 1.5 and 2 percentage points and this has reduced payments on a typical $35,000 loan from a bank or building society by between $ 40 and $50 a month.

The signs indicate clearly that our strategy to get the industry moving again has worked. Dwelling commencements increased 5 per cent in the March quarter from the very low December quarter and a further 17 per cent in the June quarter . Private house approvals, a forward indicator of activity, were 35 per cent higher in the September quarter than in the corresponding period in 1982. Lending for housing has also shown a marked improvement. We have passed from the deep depression of last year in the housing industry and every indicator this year since this Government came to power has improved. Because of the high employment multiplier effects in the housing industry and in house building activity, the benefits of this recovery will spread throughout the community, and this is particularly good news to the white-goods industry in South Australia in which Senator Foreman is so interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, can we have the paper from which the Minister quoted?
—Sure. I did not quote from it; I read it.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In view of Senator Grimes's remarks that stage 2 of the Launceston General Hospital must be built and that the Commonwealth will have to share the cost, will the Commonwealth Government fulfil its commitment to cost-share the building of a modified stage 2 of the hospital without this funding affecting the level of support to other Tasmanian hospitals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made remarks in recent weeks and recent years on the desirability of completing stage 2 of the Launceston General Hospital and I have been consistent in what I have said. The previous Government, which was in power from 1975 to 1983, never once made a commitment to the completion of stage 2 of that hospital; nor did it ever make a commitment to put one cent into that hospital. The previous Government, despite requests of previous Labor and Liberal governments in Tasmania for the previous Government to make a commitment and despite the representations made by Mr Newman, a Minister of the previous Government who lives in Launceston, never ever made that commitment. The difficulty has been that the Launceston General Hospital has been in this state of uncertainty. I agree with Senator Watson that this state of uncertainty must stop.

ANSWER.PARA: What we need to do, in my opinion, is complete stage 2 of that hospital, in a modified form or otherwise, and end up with a reasonable hospital. The best way to plan this is to look at the whole question of hospital bed needs in north- eastern Tasmania and come up with a rational hospital program for that area. That is what this Government wants to do, in combination with the State Government. We have put to the Tasmanian Government a proposal for looking at the situation in northern Tasmanian hospitals, but we are unwilling to commit funds without some idea from the Tasmanian Government as to just what its plans are and what its concepts should be. If Senator Watson really believes that we can proceed in Tasmania by building new hospitals, putting in new beds and not taking into account the need for hospital beds in other places, I believe that he is mistaken and I do not think he believes that that is a reasonable approach .

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware of some strong resistance among country people to the introduction of Telecom Australia's countrywide calling system? Does the new system disadvantage country people by increasing the cost of local calls? Can the Minister recommend a review of the new system to ensure that isolated Australians are not discriminated against in regard to communications costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reynolds was good enough to give me notice of this question and I have obtained an answer from the Minister for Communications. I am advised that countrywide calling was developed to overcome problems associated with the provision of services in sparsely settled areas. The main concern in its development centred around the need for several things: Firstly, the need for larger zones to limit expenditure on zone identification equipment; secondly, to provide customers with access to a reasonable number of people at lower call charges; thirdly, to keep community access arrangements intact. Countrywide calling benefits the majority of customers, as stated by the Minister for Communications and Telecom, by extending the area over which people can call at a reasonable rate and by enabling automatic telephone services to be provided in remote areas earlier and at less cost than under the existing zoning scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: It is understood that Telecom has received a large number of representations, perhaps complaints, from country people about countrywide calling. Clearly there is a degree of concern amongst country people about the new system. In response to these representations, I can say that the manager of trunk network services, a senior Telecom officer, has been involved in extensive consultation with country people about their concerns. He has already travelled to Goondiwindi, to the Wentworth area of New South Wales, and to Wilpena and Ceduna in South Australia, and he will go to Queensland in the next few days. Inevitably, introduction of the system has thrown up anomalies, and it is these anomalies which are being ironed out by Telecom at the moment. Wherever the manager has been, he has been able to make changes to cater for the people concerned. It should be understood that the system will enable country people to telephone a lot more people at less cost, although this has necessitated a number of local calls being charged on a timed three-minute basis. Clearly there are trade-offs in the new scheme, but the overall benefit is that it will allow much wider access at less cost to country subscribers. The matter is being continually examined by Telecom, in terms of the earlier answer I gave.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION COMMISSION: BUILDING INDUSTRY DECISION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question about the Government's call to all parties in the construction industry 'to explore all avenues' to circumvent the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Is this not proof that the Government is more concerned about industrial peace than economic recovery and jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no proposal for consultation to circumvent the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. 'Circumvent' was the honourable senator's word and nobody else's.
—I quoted the words 'to explore all avenues' too.

—The honourable senator used the word 'circumvent'. I am just making it quite clear that I am not answering a question about circumvention of the Commission's decision. The decision given by the Arbitration Commission in relation to the building trades agreement has necessitated a further process of conferences with the building industry and the building trades unions. The Government will take part in this.
—What about the employers?

—The employers do not accept it either. That necessitates a further process of conferring. The Government made it quite clear to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that, if there was to be an acceptance of the building industry agreement, it would be on the basis that it would not flow to other industries. The Arbitration Commission expressed the view that in its opinion it could not be contained. It is in respect of those matters that further conferences will take place.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis then asked me the extraordinary question as to whether this Government prefers industrial peace to economic growth. He wasted the last eight years in the Senate trying to point out to everybody else that the two things were intimately connected.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are in government; we are not.

—We are in government; that is right. Senator Lewis should not let it hurt him too much or pain him too much. We are in government and that is why I said earlier that the process of consultation on this matter will continue . If there had been a Liberal government, I do not know what would have happened . I would be grateful for some suggestion. Perhaps Senator Lewis could bring forward a matter of public importance on the subject and tell us what he would have done in the circumstances. But the realities of the situation are that industrial relations in the building trades are very difficult. The decision of the Arbitration Commission does not resolve that problem and the Government will take part in consultations to try to find a solution to that problem.

ANSWER.PARA: I was trying, when Senator Lewis became irritated by something I was saying, to say that of course the questions of industrial peace and economic growth are intimately related. This Government has been concerned right from the date of its election to see that the detriment to economic growth which was caused by so much industrial relations confrontation and trouble in the time of the Fraser Government-when people like Senator Lewis day after day, week after week, year after year blamed the industrial relations system for the chronic failures of the Fraser Government-does not happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give them anything they want.

—It is not a question of giving them anything they want. I will give Senator Lewis what he needs. It is a matter of recognising the very close relationship between the two matters which Senator Lewis puts in juxtaposition in opposition to each other.

—Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs able to report on the progress of planning to introduce a school of tropical medicine at James Cook University? Can the Minister confirm that this project will receive priority consideration, despite some apparent resistance within the Tertiary Education Commission to the development of this important research facility which is vital for the study of tropical diseases and Aboriginal health in northern Australia?

—As I announced on 28 July 1983 in the guidelines to the Tertiary Education Commission, the question of establishing such an institute is to be considered by the Commission in the context of the 1985-1987 triennium and advice will be included in the Commission's triennium report early in 1984. I would not wish to pre-empt the Commission's advice or the Government's consideration of that advice. I understand that the Universities Council of the Commission currently has this matter under consideration and as a part of this process is consulting with the Commonwealth Department of Health which also has responsibility for research in this area. I expect that this project will receive positive and constructive consideration by the Tertiary Education Commission and its bodies and it will be the subject of a Government decision after that advice is received.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the question I asked him on 2 November concerning a report of an alleged fraud of $10,000 from his Department about which the Minister used his discretion to suppress prosecution of the alleged offender. As the Minister indicated that he would check the facts and provide further details, I ask whether he is now in a position to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have checked the situation. I intended, in fact, to answer Senator Messner after Question Time this week. First of all, the fact is that there was a case involving a fraud of some $5,000, not $10,000. The case was recommended for prosecution. After representations were made to me by Mr Fry, the honourable member for Fraser, and after consideration of the facts and consultation with officers of my Department, I decided that that prosecution would not proceed although it is my understanding, certainly, that the restitution of the overpayments will proceed. The reasons for that decision were to do with the circumstances of the person involved. I thought that, as I had that discretion, in that situation it should be made.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to Senator Messner that that discretion has been available. It is my understanding that Senator Chaney made a statement saying that he had never used it. I expect that I would not use it very often. But that does not mean that it should never be used. I have had representations made to me from people on both sides of the Parliament about cases like this. I remember some years ago that I made many representations to the then Minister for Social Security about what I considered was an extremely unfortunate case of a person who was being prosecuted in circumstances not unlike this. The Minister refused to take any action in the case. When the case got to court, the magistrate discharged it and roundly condemned the authorities, the Government and the Department for ever letting the case go to court. So I suggest that, in those circumstances, there is some suggestion that that ministerial discretion is, at times, necessary.

I am unwilling, unless asked to do so by a substantive motion of this House, to name the person involved or to discuss the personal circumstances involved. I do not believe that that would be proper. I do not believe that that is a sensible thing for a Minister for Social Security to do in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer. I think I understood him to say that he did not see any bar to the seeking by the Department of restitution of funds but that he would not be proceeding to prosecute the client. As I understand it, he was also making the point that there was considerable hardship involved in the case that he mentioned. Therefore, I fail to see how he is alleviating hardship by instituting a course of restitution. I wonder, therefore, whether the Minister might give us an outline of his general reasons for taking the particular decision.

—I accept the point made by Senator Messner. Restitution was already being made when it was decided to prosecute. Restitution, as Senator Messner knows, can be made in very small amounts. But that was not the primary cause of my making the decision that I made. In considering this case I considered, firstly, the amount of money involved and, secondly, the personal circumstances of the lady involved, how many children she had, how young those children were, what the likely outcome of the penalty would be and the hardships involved in the penalty, and whether the hardships involved in such a penalty would be worse than the situation she found herself in when receiving that overpayment. It was due to a whole range of facts like that that the decision was made. I repeat to Senator Messner that I expect that it would be unlikely that I would make such a decision again or many such decisions again, but I think occasionally one has to do so.

—During Question Time earlier today Senator Chaney asked me a question about information given to the Northern Territory Government in relation to the Uluru National Park and the decision announced by the Government on 11 November in relation to that matter. I am advised that a telex was sent on the morning of 11 November to Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, and an announcement was made regarding the Commonwealth's intentions later that day. I make the point that the Commonwealth's position and intentions in relation to that National Park were not by any means new to the Northern Territory Government and the matter had been the subject of public statement and discussion. In fact, on 3 June this year the Northern Territory Chief Minister wrote to the Commonwealth Government seeking the transfer of that park area to the Northern Territory with a view, as the Chief Minister put it, to granting to the Aboriginal people perpetual title in the land at that park under Northern Territory law. The matter has been the subject of ongoing consideration. But insofar as the question was directed to the specific facts of what happened on 11 November, I provided them in an earlier part of this answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES AIR FORCE: NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Hearn asked me about the replacement of B52D aircraft stationed at Guam with B52G aircraft and asked what was happening in relation to their flying over and touching down in Australia. I welcome the report on the Australian Trade Commissioner Service that has been put down. I am pleased that the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) took the action he did in having this inquiry carried out. I do hope, however, that it is not just another inquiry and not just another report. I express the great respect that I have for the excellent gentleman who carried out the inquiry, but I do regard their findings and considerations both tentative and timid. I believe they could have taken a much more forward thinking approach to the matter at this time. One of the few things that all sectors of government and business agree on at present is that an increase in our exports and our export attacks is most necessary for the Australian economy to revive. I have to doubt that the actions proposed will produce more than a ripple when in fact a major splash is required.

The Australian Trade Commissioner Service has been looked at very regularly. Various committees of the House of Representatives have looked at various sections of it. The Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce, of which I was a member at the time, also made a parliamentary investigation into it and made recommendations. Each year there is a report on it in the report of the Department of Trade. Every second year the Department makes its own inquiry into its own operations. So it cannot be said that we have not had a good and fairly regular look at the Trade Commissioner Service. But what can be said can be instanced by the fact that the report of the Trade and Commerce Committee of 1978 and this report which has just come out are remarkably similar. The same recommendations are being made now as were made five years ago. I believe that if we are to achieve something in the operation of the Trade Commissioner Service it will need to be far more aggressive than it has been in the past. It will need to be much more flexible. I am pleased to see in the Minister's tabling statement that he refers to the increased flexibility that he hopes to be able to achieve. I also believe it is necessary to have a much clearer definition of the services that the Trade Commissioner Service provides. Everybody I know seems to expect different things of the Service. Each person sees it as performing different functions. I believe that too much is expected of the Service by many people. The definition of what the Service is there for needs to be clarified.

One of the worst areas of the Australian trade scene is the degree of competition which exists, apparently, between the Australian Trade Commissioner Service-administered by the Department of Trade-and the States. I believe that somehow or other greater co-operation has to be achieved with the States on the use of resources in our overseas posts. The Australian Trade Commissioner Service and the facilities provided have to be considered far more as part of the overall productive policy of this country, especially when it comes to matters such as taxation incentives, the Australian Industry Development Corporation and so on.
