The seventh annual report, for 1981-82, of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority raises more questions than it answers. The working capital deficit and current liabilities of $8,653,318 exceed current assets of $6,318,305. One must therefore ask how the Authority plans to meet its future commitments in these circumstances and to remain solvent. Looking at the long term liabilities and the fact that many of these debts are likely to mature shortly, one must ask what are the means of repaying the debt capital. To me it appears that the only avenue is to continue to go to the market and to borrow.

On 5 April 1973 the then Minister for the Capital Territory, the Hon. Kep Enderby, said that the Belconnen Mall was an exciting proposal, that it provided the best possible range of facilities, that it was an attractive and competitive centre, and that it would-here are the operative words-help to reduce pressure on prices. To date there has been no evidence, and certainly no explanation has been given, as to how the Belconnen Town Centre has achieved a reduction of pressure on prices to the tenants, the customers or consumers, despite that statement.

Later, looking at section 26 of the Ordinance under which the Authority was set up, we find that it was to promote the payment to the Commonwealth of Australia of a reasonable return on the capital of the Authority. So I think we need to ask whether the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) believes that the Mall development is still soundly financed. When does the Commonwealth expect the first return from such an investment? Looking at the position in relation to the carry-forward of losses and the fact that no tax will be paid, one finds that there is not very much return to the Government in the form of taxes paid as compared with what might have been paid by a similar operation under private enterprise operating very much more efficiently and paying tax.

On the basis of the cost of the assets versus the external equities, there is only a very minimal surplus, despite certain profits being earned over the period since the Mall became operative. It is true that after the revaluation of the assets, the investment on a book face looks very much sounder, but if there were a forced sale one wonders what the realisable price would be and whether the Commonwealth might have to be called upon to honour some of the debts it has backed.

I think that more people than just the Minister should be informed as to the reasons for the delay in the report. The report states that the reasons for the delay have been given to the Minister. That is not good enough. All too often statutory authorities hide behind legal restrictions and so on, and in this case the Authority certainly has done that. What were the reasons? The report states that it was a very difficult trading period. There is no directors' or chairman' s report to accompany the figures, as would be required in private enterprise. It just shows the paucity of the Government's reporting requirements and the fact that many such authorities, including the Commercial Development Authority, hide behind providing a minimum of information concerning disclosures.

Basically the investment here is made very much more attractive by the impact of inflation rather than of sound financing techniques. In spite of the fact that Mr Pead as Chairman sent the report to the Minister for Territories and Local Government in August 1983 and that Mr Pead as Chairman and Mr Elsworth as Deputy Chairman signed the accounts on 16 August 1983, they are still prepared to make this comment in the report:

The future income tax benefits arising from timing differences and past tax losses as detailed in notes C and D below have not been recognised because their eventual recovery out of future taxable income cannot be assured beyond any reasonable doubt.

Is not this an indictment by the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the future profitability of this operation? Surely they should have a bit more confidence than to make such a statement knowing full well that earlier the Government in its election promises and later had indicated that the Belconnen Mall centre was not to be sold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 212th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's earlier report No. 203-a progress report on medical fraud and overservicing. The Department of Finance minute is the formal mechanism used by the Government for responding to the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's progress report on medical fraud and overservicing was tabled in Parliament on 9 December. It contained 45 recommendations directed at streamlining and strengthening both administrative procedures and existing legislation. The report examined the effectiveness of existing legislation, procedures for dealing with abuse of the medical benefits system and a generalised discussion on other associated problems. The 203rd report raised a number of fundamental issues on public administration which extended well beyond the specific area of medical fraud and overservicing. These included the overall performance of the Department of Health, the general relationship between central and State offices of departments and the adequacy of the current legal system in coping with white collar crime.

While the Committee notes the considerable progress made to combat fraud and overservicing, it believes that there are still significant areas where further improvements need to be made. For example, it appears that the Department of Health has more than doubled its positions dedicated to reducing medical fraud and overservicing from 94, as at June 1982, to 205 as at October 1983. However in the crucial area of staff devoted to development of the Department's fraud and overservicing detection system there has been to date no increase in the number of people permanently filling positions, although the number of positions has increased from seven to 16.

Similarly, the Australian Federal Police has applied to the Public Service Board for an extra 50 positions to be dedicated to medical fraud and overservicing. This is in addition to a request for another 149 general positions in 1982-83 and 230 positions in 1983-84. The Committee will be monitoring the Board's consideration of these positions. Furthermore, while the Attorney-General's Department has created an additional 12 positions to deal with medical fraud and overservicing-a move welcomed by the Committee-at present only three of these have been filled by permanent promotees; the rest are filled by personnel on an acting basis or on temporary transfer.

The Committee considers that most senior officers in the Department of Health, the Australian Federal Police and the Attorney-General's Department now acknowledge the complexity and magnitude of the effort required to deal with medical fraud and overservicing in the Australian community. The Committee therefore welcomes the establishment of: The Surveillance and Investigation Division in the Department of Health; and a central co-ordinating committee and State co-ordinating groups containing representatives of the Department of Health, the Attorney-General's Department, the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It is clear that the development of the fraud and overservicing detection system-FODS-is of paramount importance to the success of efforts to combat medical fraud and overservicing. The Committee is not convinced that adequate resources are currently being devoted to this task. At present the 14 main FODS development activities of the Department of Health may take up to 230 man months to complete.

The Committee noted with interest the National Prosecutors Seminar conducted by the Attorney-General's Department in April 1983. The Committee believes it is necessary for such a seminar to be held regularly in order to update and share knowledge of prosecution information among relevant Commonwealth officers. The Committee has been informed that 37 medical practitioner disqualification actions were in progress as at 30 September 1983. A breakdown of the Central Co- ordinating Committee's caseload as a September 1983 reveals: A substantial overall increase in medifraud cases-502 in total; higher medifraud caseloads in New South Wales and Victoria relative to other States; and a considerable backlog of cases, listed more than six months ago, awaiting action in the Department of Health.

I turn to the Medicare national health scheme. It should be emphasised that the Committee cannot and does not question the adequacy of government policies but is concerned with their administrative implementation. During discussions with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), the Committee was informed that the current departmental estimate of the cost of fraud and overservicing by doctors is in the vicinity of $120m per annum. It is noted that at least one professional medical society believes this estimate should be closer to $200m per annum. The Committee believes that resources in the Department of Health currently devoted to investigation and prevention of medical fraud and overservicing should not be diverted to aid the introduction of Medicare. Efforts to control and reduce medical fraud and overservicing are a necessary complement to the introduction and successful operation of the Medicare scheme.

The Committee is pleased to see legislation being introduced to implement many of its recommendations. However, it notes with concern that the Department of Health has not made significant progress in implementing the new overservicing committee system referred to in the Department of Finance minute. The Public Accounts Committee acknowledges that extensive new legislation may be required to implement a new overservicing committee system but believes such legislation will be vital to the containment of medical benefit costs under the Medicare scheme. The Committee notes that latest official estimates suggest a markedly higher supply of doctors in the coming years. It remains concerned that as mechanisms to control and reduce medical fraud become more effective, there will be an increase in the level of overservicing by medical practitioners.
The Committee's inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing is continuing and I look forward to presenting the final report to Parliament next year. I commend this report to honourable senators.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name for the disallowance of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority (Amendment) Ordinance and Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 for Thursday, 17 November 1983, standing in my name for the disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance, be postponed till Tuesday, 29 November 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) whether the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was misled when it inquiried into the cannibalisation of spare parts in relation to certain aircraft and was advised that this practice would be discontinued as a result of the increased allocation of moneys for the supply of spare parts, improved accounting procedures, improved communications system, et cetera. It was distressing to hear again this year that cannibalisation has been practised on a reasonably wide scale, particularly in the Royal Australian Air Force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best way I can answer the honourable senator's question is as follows: There is no acceptance of the practice of cannibalisation as a routine source of repair parts. Temporary cannibalisation of parts from an aircraft undergoing long term maintenance or repair for use on another aircraft to meet a short term operational need is a common practice in other air forces, airlines and many large scale operators of complex equipment. To totally eliminate such cannibalisation would require prohibitive investment in spares support. Temporary cannibalisation is only adopted as a result of a specific management decision when the urgency of repair precludes any other arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a deliberate attempt to increase the proportion of expenditure devoted to capital equipment and to contain expenditure on maintenance support items, but there is no evidence that the incidence of cannibalisation in the RAAF is increasing. The need to cannibalise parts from one aircraft to maintain another can spring from a number of causes not necessarily restricted to the provision of funding for spare parts. For example, production or delivery delays , first time failures and engineering repair problems can also contribute to the need. I understand that that answer is consistent with what was stated to the Public Accounts Committee. There may be some differences of emphasis or interpretation involved, but that is as accurately as the Department and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) can relay the present state of affairs.

While I am on my feet, I take the opportunity to reply to a number of matters that were raised by Senator Watson and Senator Sir John Carrick during the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Defence on 10 November, last week. The first matter, the taxation of earnings of Rerserve personnel, was raised by Senator Watson and was adverted to by Senator Sir John Carrick. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Defence announced on 9 November that half of the earnings of reservists would be free of tax. It therefore follows that the rate of tax on total Reserve pay will be a maximum of 30 per cent, but even lower for those in lower income brackets. No tax will be deducted in respect of any earnings before 1 December 1983, whether or not the amount is paid after that date. As I mentioned last week, the decision is generous by comparison with what others pay in tax on their extra marginal income.

In March 1975 the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay concluded that there was a difference in skill efficiency and professionalism between the regular soldier and part time reservist and the pay rates should be different as between those categories. In August 1982 the Committee last quantified the difference at 90 per cent of Regular Force rates for officers up to the rank of major and its equivalent and 85 per cent above the rank of major and its equivalent. On the question of the actual pay rates, the Committee has been asked to review rates of Reserve pay and allowances in the light of the Government's decision and to report no later than 30 June 1984. If possible, the Committee will no doubt report before then. Senator Watson referred also in this context to a tax free sum for regulars who re-engage. This re-engagement bounty will be phased out from 26 September 1984 except for some regulars who joined the Defence Force as apprentices. There is no intention to review policy on the bounty.

Senator Watson also raised questions about Army Reserve training, morale and severances. During 1982-83 recruitment for the Army Reserve was more successful than expected, which resulted in numbers exceeding the authorised strength. In 1983-84 it is planned to retain the existing authorised strength of 30,000 members. It is also planned to reduce the average number of training days from 38.25 to 36, which was the allocation for Army Reserve training prior to the expansion two years ago. The figure of 36 days, as an average training per man per year, has been generally accepted by the senior officers of the Army Reserve as being a realistic figure without involving a reduction in functions or activities. Defence has no evidence to support either any general lowering of morale or a 40 per cent severance rate, although no doubt there are individual instances, about which the honourable senator has information and can cite, of dissatisfaction with the state of affairs.

A further question raised by Senator Watson concerned staffing in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. There is a need, which was recently highlighted by the reviews of DSTO, to provide its scientists and engineers with more support through additional equipment and operating resources. Within a tightly constrained defence budget DSTO manpower is, therefore, being reduced by a net 80 in 1983-84 in a total of about 4,500. The manpower resources thus saved are being traded for an increase in operating and equipment support. Reductions are being directed to those areas of activity which are least supportive of the Organisation's service customers. Reductions are intended to be achieved by selective non-replacement of natural wastage. There will be no retrenchments in that area.

As to the balance between civilian and military costs, a matter which was also raised by Senator Watson, the main reason for the civilian increase is the provision of $3.811m for redundancy payments to some 200 locally engaged civilians who have been retrenched as a consequence of the withdrawal of one Mirage squadron from Butterworth to Darwin in August 1983. There is no increase in civilian manpower numbers for the Department of Defence. To the contrary, the 1983-84 Budget provides for average civilian employment this year of 24,698 compared with 24,957 in 1982-83.

Senator Watson also raised a question-I think it involved someone at Butterworth-concerning the promotion of a person from corporal to flight sergeant and the net pay involved. While the circumstances cited would not appear to be correct in the case of a flight sergeant, such an occurrence could apply in the case of a married corporal who was promoted to sergeant. This would be due to the effect of the higher salary on overseas allowance payments. It has been the Department's practice to take the Public Service Board's structured allowance systems and apply them to servicemen overseas, with a minor variation for servicemen's medical arrangements. In the light of the case of a corporal promoted to sergeant, it is intended to review this aspect of procedure for calculating overseas allowances.

Senator Watson also adverted to communications support at the RAAF base at Butterworth. The answer to the issue he raised is this: No Reserve communications personnel are employed by the RAAF at Butterworth. However, some Reserve officers are regularly posted to Butterworth because it provides an opportunity for them to be employed in a way which allows them to exercise their specialist skills. Whether Senator Watson will be satisfied with that answer or whether he will regard it as a restatement of the question remains to be seen, but I am afraid that I cannot do any better than that for him.

The question of Mirage aircraft also attracted Senator Watson's enthusiastic attention. A further and, I hope, better answer is as follows: The application of modern aircraft technology can allow the operations of aircraft to be regulated so that the effects of structural fatigue can be kept within safe margins. This technology has been applied to the Mirage and has resulted in the imposition of temporary flight restrictions on some aircraft and periodic inspection of fatigue prone areas. To return the Mirage to unrestricted operations and to further ensure the aircraft's structural integrity, the RAAF has embarked on programs to: Firstly, refurbish fatigue-damaged wings; secondly, procure new wings to replace the most fatigue-damaged wings; thirdly, inspect and refurbish fatigue-critical regions in the fuselages of high life aircraft-I am fascinated with the description; it means aircraft which are many hours old- and, fourthly, in conjunction with the Aeronautical Research Laboratories, the Mirage manufacturer and the Swiss Government, conduct tests to determine the fatigue life of the Mirage subsequent to the refurbishment program. By such well established means are the airworthiness of the Mirage and the safety of pilots assured.

Senator Watson was concerned also to find out the situation with respect to Skyhawk and Tracker aircraft. A review of Australian coastal surveillance is presently under way. This review is being conducted on behalf of Mr Beazley in his capacity as Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. The use of Tracker aircraft for coastal surveillance will be studied as part of this review. Four Skyhawk aircraft continue to be used for target towing in support of fleet training. These four aircraft are to be withdrawn from service in mid-1984 subject to the introduction of a suitable replacement target system.

Senator Watson wanted some further particulars about the FA18 costs. I am able to oblige him as follows: The original project approval was expressed in August 1981 prices with an exchange rate of $A1 equalling $US1.1484. When project approval was last revised it was expressed in December 1982 prices and took into consideration the March 1983 devaluation. The exchange rate used was $A1 equals $US 0.8650. As announced by the Minister for Defence, this difference alone required an increase of $A777.638m to the project approval which assumed the continuation of the March 1983 exchange rate. However, the value of the Australian dollar has since increased in relation to the United States dollar and hopefully this trend will continue.

As to Navy steaming and Army training times-a preoccupation of Senator Sir John Carrick-I am able to give him further and better particulars as follows: As to Navy steaming time, during 1981-82 and 1982-83, 86,048 and 84,049 tonnes of dieso fuel respectively were used by the Navy for fleet activities. For 1983-84 Navy has set the dieso fleet fuel allowance at 68,848 tonnes. Measures such as an increase in the number of fleet deployments together with single engine boiler running and reduced maximum speeds will help to reduce fuel usage and increase fuel efficiency. Actual usage of furnace fuel oil during 1981-82 and 1982-83 was 19,423 and 20,450 tonnes respectively. Planned usage for 1983-84 is 18,561 tonnes.

Finally, as to Army track running, I am able to advise those senators who are still interested in these matters that Army will increase its M113 and tank training allowances by 10,000 and 1,000 kilometers respectively in 1983-84. I believe that this picks up all the various loose ends in relation to the Defence estimates that were left trailing at our last meeting. I hope that honourable senators will be duly satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: He said squadrons were managing to meet their targets by cannibalising parts from 'Christmas tree' aeroplanes, as well as by changing engines more often . . .

There has been no major constraint on spares provisioning. There is therefore no reason caused by the means which have been imposed for there to be a substantial problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Tasmania)-by leave-Estimates Committee E found in its examination of the estimates of various departments that there seemed to be some ill understanding of the Minister for Finance's seeking of $53m for expenditure in respect of salaries and administrative expenses for the commencement, continuation or expansion of government programs. We report that fact to the Committee and note that there seems to be some new category emerging in appropriations under Division 312 of the estimates for the Department of Finance. The fact is that the Committee is very concerned that there seems to be a move away from the urgent and unforeseen criteria governing the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, which has become a fairly regular feature of parliamentary appropriations. We are concerned that there is a provision for the servicing by providing of salaries and so on within the Public Service of new programs, which new programs are not coming before the Parliament in a way which enables the Senate to deal with them because they are in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) rather than in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). I know this will be of concern to Senator Peter Rae who is keen on Senate surveillance of such matters. I cannot go into the full details of all this except to say that a reply was received from the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, to Senator Sibraa and to the concern of the Committee. Amongst other things, it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For purposes of Parliamentary control and disclosure the Government considered that the global provision-
that is the $53m-

should be subject to specific conditions which would allow Parliament to be informed fully of the eventual disposition of the provision. Those conditions-as expressed within Division 312-are designed to meet those aims.

In other words, there is an attempt to suggest that somehow Parliament would be fully informed of the eventual disposition of the provision. I would turn the words around and say that what he is really saying is that we would be eventually informed of the full disposition of the funds rather than that we would be fully informed of the eventual dispostion. In other words, after the event, the Senate might be informed of what was going on with this $53m. When one looks at the conditions in Division 312 to get some assurance that the Senate would find a means of putting the expenditure of these moneys under scrutiny, it states:
Division 312.-SPECIAL FUNDS FOR EXPENDITURE IN RELATION TO GOVERNMENT PROGRAMS AT THE DIRECTION OF THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE
To enable the Minister for Finance to make moneys available for expenditure in respect of salaries and payments in the nature of salaries and administrative expenses, being expenditure-
(a) that the Minister for Finance from time to time determines is necessary for the commencement, continuation or expansion of Government programs;
(b) particulars of which will, as soon as practicable after he has so determined, be submitted to the Parliament; and
(c) that is expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

In fact that does not put Parliament or the Senate in any position to put those proposed expenditures under any real scrutiny. It provides an after the event submission to the Parliament of how the funds have been spent. Certainly, it is not a condition in the sense of enabling something to be fulfilled within this chamber before the funds are dispersed for those purposes. The fact is that in the accord which was struck between the House of Representatives and the Senate some years ago, the idea was that new programs should be placed in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which is amendable by the Senate, and that ordinary annual services expenditure be in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) as a continuing part of providing for departmental salaries, et cetera. Division 312, which is commented upon by Estimates Committee E, seems to create a situation which allows the financing of new policies not previously authorised and not put under separate scrutiny by the Senate by their inclusion in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which is amendable by the Senate. This new practice seems to allow the growth of new policies and new initiatives by Government without the possibility of that sort of scrutiny by the Senate. I raise this for the purpose of elaborating to honourable senators on the report to the Senate by Estimates Committee E and hope that we can get some clarification.
