TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I suggest that the Senate have a general debate covering this Bill, the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase) Bill and the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a general debate covering the three Bills? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak with brevity on the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill 1983, the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase) Bill 1983 and the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1983 only because I have been asked to keep my speech short to encourage the passage of some legislation, following a fairly lengthy period of consideration of the Appropriation Bills. For that reason I will curtail the remarks which I would otherwise have made in indicating that the Opposition supports the Bills, and in particular the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill which provides for an additional subscription by Australia. The position is that Australia and the other nations in the area covered by the Asian Development Bank are trading partners of very great significance. It is important for us to remember the nature of the Asian-Pacific region and the developments which not only have taken place but which will take place in what is so often termed the Western Pacific. The Opposition warmly and strongly supports the development of trade, industry, commerce and financial links with those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to be taken as ignoring the existence of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has called a ripple on an otherwise harmonius relationship but I do not want to debate that when I am talking about trade and economic and financial affairs. I mention it only to show that I have not ignored it. I think it is far more important at the moment, in relation to these Bills, to look at the developments which have taken place. After the creation of the European Economic Community and Britain's belated but very real joining of that Economic Community , Australia found itself in a position in which it had to reorganise its trading relationships. It had to find and help develop completely new markets and had to ensure that it was able to offset the tremendous trade disadvantages which befell it as a result of the creation of the European Economic Community and particularly the development of the common agricultural policy which had such a significant and harsh impact on various sections of Australian industry. One of the things it is important for us to remember in looking at any of these matters is that something that adversely affects primary industry has a follow through adverse effect on secondary and tertiary industries in Australia. There is no way we can say that it affects just one sector. The impact of the common agricultural policy on Australia is important, and it is important, when we start to look at the development of the economies of the areas of the world with which we are now able to develop new and I hope lasting and mutually beneficial relationships, that we look also at Australia's role and position as an international trader and whether or not it can hold its head up high in that respect.

One of the important aspects of this role is one about which Australia, I think often unjustly, is accused or misunderstood. I refer to the question of protection. Australia is probably a high protection country only to the extent that anyone accepts that if a country is absolutely honest and has its protection out front where everybody can see it, it can be characterised as being high protection when it is being compared with some of the countries that have lowered their obvious barriers while raising innumerable other barriers to prevent the free trade which so many people piously espouse but so seldom practise. I think it is relevant that we have regard to Australia's position with regard to the Asian Development Bank and the economic development of the Association of South East Asian Nations and Western Pacific regions. Australia has 84.2 per cent of its imports from ASEAN countries cleared at non-protective rates of duty. It has 99.4 per cent of its imports from Papua New Guinea cleared at non-protective rates of duty. For the most recent year the Australian average , overall, was 70 per cent. These are all indications I think that, for a country which has its methods of protection very obvious, we have done a great deal to try, firstly, to encourage the development of the ASEAN countries and the Western Pacific region and, secondly, to make known and obvious where our trade protection barriers lie. There are many other figures that maybe I ought to refer to, but I do not wish to take up the time of the Senate in doing that. I just say that thousands of trade barriers are raised by other countries by methods, which are not used by Australia to impede the free flow of trade.

When we look at Australia's role in the development of the economic region I think it is important that we bear in mind that Australia is playing an important and a co-operative part in the development of the economies of the region. The economies of this region have been, for a significant period, subject in many ways to the dominance of Japan. Japan has been the earliest of the super-economies, the new economies, to develop. But the newly industrialised countries such as the Republic of Korea, the People's Republic of China, the ASEAN countries and the Province of Taiwan have all shown remarkable figures in their various ways. The current figures indicate that the growth that is taking place in the world, as it comes out of recession, is taking place earlier and faster in the ASEAN countries and the Western Pacific region than anywhere else. That being so, I believe the activities of the Asian Development Bank and the sympathies of the International Monetary Fund are highly desirable when one looks at this sort of development.

One of the concerns I express in relation to the IMF is that the economies of the world have now become very substantially subjected to the wisdom and the dictates of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Certainly a large percentage of the members of the OECD itself are not able to successfully put forward different economic policies from those approved by the OECD and expect to get an approval rating from the OECD. I think that the IMF tends to be influenced a little in a similar direction. One of my concerns is that we do not have a situation in which there is a flood of thought suddenly flashing around the world, particularly between some of the major bankers of the IMF, who undoubtedly have substantial influence with it, and those who are the creditors of the major debtor countries, such as Mexico, Brazil, Argentina and Poland, which could induce a situation whereby the purchasers of raw materials from countries such as that are induced to buy from those debtor countries to enable those debtors to service their international debts. If that were to happen Australia's responsibility in its borrowing programs will have been repaid by a clear and savage detriment to its trading capacity. I believe it is one of the aspects of responsibility that needs to be borne in mind when we talk about our participation in a number of these international economic and financial organisations.

The strength of the economies of South East Asia and of the whole of the Western Pacific region is certainly one of the surprises, perhaps to many people of world development in recent times. In the period from 1977 to 1981 the ASEAN countries showed a growth rate of about 8 per cent, compared with Australia's average growth rate of 0.6 per cent. Forecasts indicate that countries such as Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand are likely to experience a growth rate, in real terms, of around 6 per cent. The most recent revised estimates would probably put the figure even higher than that. The figures for the Republic of Korea and the Province of Taiwan would probably go quite substantially higher than that.

Australia's position, in terms of a real gross domestic product estimate of the order of 3 per cent, if it does take place, will show a significant improvement. The figure for the ASEAN area is likely to be higher than those for Latin America, Africa and South Africa, and the OECD average of 3 to perhaps 3.5 per cent. What we are looking at is Australia's participation, for the benefit of the whole of the region, in the development of that region and in a trading relationship which is based on mutual trust to the benefit of both. I believe it can be done. I believe it must be done. I believe Australia must continue to play its part in providing funds such as those to the Asian Development Bank which have enabled it to assist in a lot of the development that has taken place .

Time does not permit me to go into more detail than that but, in carrying out what I was asked to do I indicate but briefly our support for these developments , our support for the part we play in the region and our support and enthusiasm for the potentiality of the region and for Australia's opportunity, an opportunity which it must not lose, to participate to an even greater extent in the growth which will take place in the Western Pacific region. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats support the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill, the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase) Bill and the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill with no great enthusiasm. They authorise Australian support for a variety of foreign aid mechanisms. The Bills call for no special comment except for the fact that they are aid Bills. I wish to raise one or two general points in that direction. The first is that the Bills deal with multilateral aid. Funds are to be provided to several large organisations- the International Development Association, the International Monetary Fund and the Asian Development Bank-and later dispensed by these organisations, generally to governments. This is where our want of enthusiasm comes in. It is notorious that in Third World countries particularly governments do not use aid well or effectively. At best they use the aid inappropriately, as I will shortly describe, but at worst that aid is used by a small class of people who wear a number of hats-that is, people who are in government, who are contractors and who have businesses-and who use that money to their ends and not to the benefit of the people of the country at large.

SPEECH.PARA: This practice has become notorious. I think it has become notorious to the extent that even the Australian people now understand that there is something wrong in the situation of aid disposal, something which needs government examination at close level. I believe the Government ought to have looked even more closely in these Bills at whether money we are giving out is used in the best possible way in which it could be used. I know that many members of the Government-honourable senators and honourable members with whom I have discussed these matters-are deeply concerned about them. I think the time has come when we ought to look far more carefully at every aid dollar of any kind whatsoever that goes out from this country and at attaching conditions to it, not political conditions, not conditions designed to score our own political points, but conditions which are well established and well known by people who are authoritative in this area, to ensure that that money is spent in ways which would be of service to a world which, heaven knows, needs it badly enough. Only too small an amount of money is being spent where it is needed.

We are not at all convinced that these Bills represent the best way to give aid . In support of this I refer back to the excellent record we had after the war with the Colombo Plan and similar projects. We were able to provide money and technical expertise to a large variety of small projects. Small though the projects were, in every case they were important in themselves. Quite often they were very dependent on the person whom we placed there and on the expertise which this country provided with the money. Projects at the village level in the areas of real importance in South East Asia in particular were very greatly appreciated. Those projects, although small, were terribly important in themselves because the problems of poverty, health, and material deprivation in Asia are truly enormous in their scope. However, on an individual scale the problem appears small. In other words, material deprivation is enormous. In terms of actual human contact we find that most people, not only of Asia but also the rest of the world, in fact do not live in cities but live in villages. People in the Third World share much the same kind of problem. Aid should be identified and isolated completely to that area.

The difficulty is that the world is not solving the real problems in this regard. The real problems are not tackled. They become worse as the years pass and much worse as the decades pass. Therefore, the fevers and the killing diseases such as malaria are now on the increase in the world. They are not on the decrease. The world is becoming a more unhealthy place, not a healthier place. A recent estimate claimed that 2,000 children now die every day in this world from starvation and a further 1,700 die every day from water related infectious diseases. This is the world which we claim is the world in which progress is being made. It should not be beyond the capacity of the world to solve these problems. However, they will be solved only when it is understood that massive dams, nuclear power houses, tyre factories, electrical appliance factories and factories which manufacture similar material goods of western society are simply not appropriate forms of aid and, indeed, are damaging.

Before I came to this place I had a spell for a while as an adviser to a government in Thailand. I was located in north-east Thailand at that time and I was able to observe at first hand one of the first tributary projects of the once vaunted Mekong development scheme which honourable senators may remember from the past as being a scheme put up in world terms as something that would save Indo China. This first tributary scheme was the Nam Pong dam near Khon Kaen in north-eastern Thailand. As far as I could see it was looked at by engineers and everybody else but the people who were competent to study the effect it would have on the people of that region. As it happened, the only place in that area where one could put a dam was a big plain with low hills around it on which only a very shallow body of water could be retained. Unfortunately, that place was one of the few pieces of arable and reliable rice land in the whole region. It had been settled by families who had been there for many generations, possibly centuries. These people had farmed the land year after year, decade after decade. They were thrown off their land. They were not given satisfactory land in compensation; they were given small amounts of money. That scheme which in the end provided electric power for one or two small country centres and which, I understand still is not operating at full capacity, was an international disaster of the worst order. It was very expensive and it did nothing but harm.

It is time we appreciated that that sort of thing ought to stop. Countries like Australia which are giving aid ought to be sure that they do not contribute to that sort of thing. We should have sufficient sense of responsibility to know that one does not solve these problems simply by throwing money at them. In fact , by simply throwing money, one quite often can cause problems, difficulties and inequalities in societies which are very grievous and very difficult and which do more harm than good.

The need, plainly, is to build on the existing village society, which has its values and virtues, which is a firm and reliable structure, and has been for a long time. It survives remarkably well in spite of the repercussions of all the financial and political crises that occur in the Asian capitals. The Thais have a proverb: 'The rule of the government stops at the bamboo wall'. That means the bamboo wall surrounding the village. The insulation is there. There is no reason why anything that happens in the capital basically will effect that society. Yet , that society needs help. When we realise that, the requirements should become plain, even obvious, to anybody who takes a little trouble to try to understand them.

Those 1,700 children who die every day from water related diseases die largely due to the fact that all sources of water supply, which are mainly wells, are permanently and irretrievably infected with a number of diseases. They are that way because it is not possible to provide economically the villages of the world , in which, I repeat, the majority of the people of this world live, with a roofing structure which will provide a safe, clean source of drinking water and cooking water to the people. This is because village houses almost entirely throughout the world are thatched in one form or another. In my experience, sufficient money has been provided in only a very small number of cases for the purchase of corrugated iron. However, this sort of construction has not worked for a number of reasons. Corrugated iron is intolerably hot when it is on a village roof. In addition, corrugated iron rusts out at the nail holes and is very difficult to fasten to bamboo purlines and roof materials which are normally found in a village house.

It emerges then that a cheap means of putting a roof on houses of this kind, which, I repeat, are the most numerous residences in the world, boils down to the solving of a fairly simple problem-the provision of some kind of roofing that can deliver clean water to a simple storage tank with a single tap inside a house. This probably is the most important technical development the world could imagine at this time in terms of being of use to the greatest number of people. Yet, such a concept is neglected; one never hears of it. But such a development would probably save at least 1,000 of those 1,700 lives that are lost every day.

The heat difficulty could possibly be overcome by using aluminium which is light and easy to transport and does not corrode. It could be carried in rolls on people's backs or in buffalo wagons. There is a need for something which can be carried by hand or by buffalo because, whether we like it or not, they remain the chief forms of transport in the world. A fastening, perhaps in the form of a hook with a rubber seal and a wing nut on top, could be used so that the material could be attached to bamboo purlins of houses of that sort without tools. I believe that such a concept could completely transform the health problems for the majority-I repeat 'the majority'-of the human race. Yet, it is not done.

I suggest to the Government that maybe here is one area where there is a special responsibility. Can we not get a task force of Australian experts- perhaps we could engage one of our aluminium manufacturers-at least to look at this problem? This is something big that we could do. Basically it is a simple problem which should not defy solution. I think it should be given a very high priority. I hope that I have convinced honourable senators that it is a problem of tremendous importance against which the development of nuclear power, microchip technology and so on are minuscule in human terms. These things are really not important to the majority of the human race although they may seem important to us.

The Australian Democrats believe that now our economy is improving we should be prepared to give more in overseas aid. We may feel we have problems in this country. We do have problems in this country but those problems are not important when they are contrasted to the needs of the Third World. It is not good enough for us to believe that we should have things that other people should not have. There is no difference whatsoever in the relationship we have with Third World peoples and the relationship we have with the people of Melbourne or Sydney. Yet, we do not take the view that the disadvantaged people in our own society should continue to be disadvantaged to the point where their children die in large numbers every day. Why then can we not construe this a little further and be of some real assistance to people in other countries where those things do happen?

In 1971, which is a fair while ago, the United Nations called for developed countries, including Australia, to give 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product as official development assistance. We got up to 0.65 per cent, to our credit, in 1975 under a Labor Government. Our allocation, however, slipped to 0.48 per cent this year, which I think was a slight increase-there, again, I commend the Government-on the figure for the previous year. Recently our rate of aid has fallen faster than that of any other donor country. Despite the domestic, social and economic crises Australia is experiencing we must be prepared to do better than this and help those in desperate need both in Australia and overseas. We cannot be content to make excuses. As I said, the worst excuse of all is that we do not spend our money properly, well and wisely; we give our money to somebody but we do not see that the money is spent on things that are most useful.

My second point at this stage is that we need to change our priorities in dispensing the amount of aid we give and the way in which it is given. Too much of Australia's aid budget, which is $822m for 1983-84, does not benefit the poorest countries of the world, where it is most needed. Laos, Nepal, Ethiopia, Chad, Somalia and Mali receive little or no aid from Australia, despite their ranking amongst the 10 poorest countries. That is an indictment of our society and it is an indictment of those who determine our aid policies. It is not good enough that that should happen.

Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, the Philippines, Fiji, Thailand and Malaysia, which are among the more affluent and best organised of the Third World countries, although they have problems, receive almost all our aid allocations. Although none of them is in fact among the 30 poorest countries in the world, we are cynically giving this aid for political purposes rather than giving it where the need is greatest. I ask the Government to look at the situation again with all honesty and try to change it, and if necessary fight a few bureaucrats who would have us do otherwise. I am not at all convinced that those people who are now determining how our aid is to be spent are capable or competent to do it in the best possible way. In fact, I am quite sure that they are not.

I am informed by some of my advisers on this matter from the voluntary aid organisations, which I believe should be given more help, that 75 per cent of our total aid budget-some $621m-is given in bilateral aid from government to government. That highlights the sorts of problems I mentioned when I first got up to speak. It is not possible to have a situation in which the majority of people who need the aid will get it if it is given. It is in the interests of the members of the average Asian government, which comprises a class of people who got themselves up to the top of the heap by their boot straps, to stay there and to see that their children stay there. Having worked with these people as an adviser for a couple of years, Mr Acting Deputy President, I can tell you that that is so. It is not unnatural that it should be so. These people do not see a particular degree of responsibility to the total population of their country; they have never seen that. In the hills of Laos, when one gets up amongst the Meo tribesmen one finds that they will let a village that has lost its land starve to death rather than help it because they do not see that they have a responsibility in that regard. That just happens to be the way they are, but it should not be the way we are. If we do not recognise that fact, then we are conniving with them. We know what is right and proper; they may not do so. Perhaps there is an excuse for them; there is no excuse for us.

The Australian Development Assistance Bureau, which is dispensing aid under the umbrella of the Department of Foreign Affairs, has allowed too much attention to be paid to Australian foreign policy priorities in determining aid. The countries I mentioned make that fairly plain. By contrast, I should like to look at one of the voluntary organisations. I will choose the Save the Children Fund, not for any particular reason but because it is a good example. This fund operates genuinely and properly in some of the poorest countries in the world. It operates in Ethiopia, Bangladesh, India, Laos, Nepal, Sudan and Lesotho. However, unfortunately, less than one per cent of Australia's overseas aid goes through the non-government organisations, which are dependent on raising money in the community. Yet those organisations are probably the most competent to judge where aid is best spent and the most competent to spend it rightly and properly and in a way which is independent of our other objectives. Our diplomatic objectives are obviously important, but I think they should not be considered with foreign aid as a sort of string or as a weapon to be used. That is a bad habit we ought to get out of.

One of the real problems is that government to government aid usually ends up in infrastructure projects, such as building roads, which often help the wealthy more than the poor. What is the use of having roads in a societal area where people cannot afford motor cars or motor cycles and will not be able to afford them in the foreseeable future? In village areas most of the villages do not have a road leading to them and one gets to them by walking across the track between the paddy fields, or at best buffalo carts have access. The roads, of course, are useful to the wealthy. They are useful to government officials and they are useful for military purposes, but they will not help the people. Aid to governments-this has happened in several South East Asian countries-can be used for political oppression. Roads can be built to give the government more control over the population. Furthermore, giving this sort of aid tends to liberate other resources and governments which wish to use political oppression, such as sending armies to invade East Timor, have all the more advantage to do so.

I am not really blaming the Labor Government; I think it has inherited a situation which it may not realise needs changing profoundly, and I am hoping it will do so. Unwittingly or not, the Australian Government in its present methodology is aiding the military campaigns of recipient governments and abetting the suppression of human rights. A clear case can be made for that argument in a number of countries. It seems to me that there is a very compelling case for the Government now to consider channelling a great deal more aid through non-government agencies such as the Save the Children Fund, which can give the assistance where it is most needed, free of the restraints of foreign policy considerations. I put this forward to the Government as a serious suggestion and as a matter of tremendous importance in world terms. I ask the Government also to think about getting together a task force of people, which could include some bureaucrats if the Government wishes-they have their value from time to time-but which would also include people from the voluntary aid organisations such as Community Aid Abroad and the Save the Children Fund. This task force could lay down a set of clear guidelines as to what kinds of aid projects the Third World needs most. Then it could come down to individual concrete proposals, perhaps such as the one I put up for decent roofing materials. Those proposals could then be analysed and discussed point by point and justified, with public input from everyone who knows, and there are many who know much more about it than I do. The Government could then come out and say: ' Here we have it. After a year of work this task force has said to us that these are the things that need doing. Here are the means to do it. This particular organisation knows what to do in this particular country. It has contacts there. This is to be done'.

The final point might be made that if we say to a government, 'This is the way aid has to be dispensed', it will say to us: 'We do not want your aid'. That is not actually happening. The Netherlands does this sort of thing, for instance. It is very careful about the way it deals with project-oriented aid and it is finding receptive governments. Once a government knows that a country is determined to make its aid dollar tell, it will respect that country all the more. So I suggest to the Government that it should consider this suggestion. I know from conversations I have had that it will get tremendous willing support immediately from the voluntary organisations to get that task force going. Let the task force be practical. Let it not look at ideas and generalities and motherhood statements, but let it look at things that really need doing and islolate them. This country could perhaps make for itself a name of great honour in the world by getting down to giving those people the money and doing those things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill, the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase) Bill and the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill. I wish first of all to deal with the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1983. It was indicated by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) in his second reading speech that the purpose of the Bill was to seek parliamentary approval for Australia to take up its entitlement to subscribe to additional shares in the capital stock of the Asian Development Bank. Last year I spoke in some detail on the Asian Development Fund Bill. The Asian Development Fund is the soft lending arm of the ADB. Last year's Bill was concerned with the replenishment of the fund and the authorisation of an increase in Australia's responsibility from 5 per cent to 7 per cent. Both Bills raise the difficult subject of foreign aid, more particularly the role, form and volume of such a responsibility which Australia does or should accept.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is aware of the Jackson Aid Review Committee inquiry into Australia' s foreign aid which is currently taking place. I for one am looking forward to the publication of that report. The Senate will also be aware that Australia's foreign aid contribution this year is 0.48 per cent of gross national product compared with 0.4 per cent last year and set against the 1983-84 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of about 0.49 per cent. I remind the Senate of the goal of 0.7 per cent called for by the United Nations in its plan for a new international economic order, a goal to which Australia acceded. The Senate will also be aware, and this reinforces the point made by Senator Mason, that 74.3 per cent of Australia's foreign aid is bilateral whereas 23.8 per cent is multilateral. The bilateral proportion is dominated by our aid to Papua New Guinea. Some 48.6 per cent of total bilateral aid goes to Papua New Guinea, or 36.1 per cent of our total aid program. That country particularly dominates our aid program, as was indicated also by Senator Mason.

The Senate will be aware of the criticisms, particularly from non-government organisations, that aid is not sufficiently reaching those in need. By this Bill we are again exhibiting support for the concept of multilateral aid as opposed to bilateral aid, and particularly multilateral aid within our region. In promoting that approach we are somewhat in conflict with the approach of the United States of America which is tending to downgrade multilateral aid in favour of bilateral aid which, of course, allows greater influence in relation to choice of development projects and in the relationship with the donee state. In last year's replenishment of the ADF, the United States of America reduced its contribution from 22 per cent to 16 per cent. We helped to make up the shortfall. In more recent times there have been even more vocal objections from within the United States Congress.

I have argued before that the very reason for the cooling of attitude in the United States towards multilateral aid, that is, having less ability to influence politically the donee state, is the very reason why we in Australia should warm to multilateral assistance. But this does however place a major responsibility upon the multilateral organisation such as the ADB in determining its priorities, in choosing between donee states, in determining which donee state should be entitled to soft loans, in determining the type of project it will finance bearing in mind the criticisms I have mentioned from non- governmental organisations, its evaluation of the success of projects financed and questions of that nature. The cursory and somewhat superficial assessment of the Bank and its undertakings as indicated in the second reading speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) wherein he states 'We have regarded it as an effective and efficient vehicle for regional co-operation and development' is therefore disappointing.

The sort of subject which I thought might have been covered and which would have been worth while to cover is how the Bank is integrating its objectives with the development policy of individual developing member countries. A discussion on that subject would have been particularly helpful. For example, I note that this year the Bank sponsored a high level symposium on development strategies in Asia which seems to reflect a growing awareness of, being sensitive to, and responding to, national development priorities. The attitude of the Bank to human resource development is also obviously of great importance as more developing countries become aware of the need to develop human resources as an integral part of their economic development planning. The building up of human capital does not appear to have been a major priority of the Bank to date. However, I have noted that the Bank is now saying that it will switch from a project-oriented approach to training to an integrated one serving a wider range of training needs. That is perhaps encouraging.

Having a developmental role with economic growth as its central factor one might ask whether the Bank has sufficiently recognised the need to avoid serious and irreversible damage to natural resources and the environment in such economic development. This is particularly so bearing in mind that developing member countries of the Bank tend to have rapidly growing populations with a need for food, coal, fuel and shelter, which invariably strains the supporting capacity of the local environment. The Bank acknowledges that this often results in overgrazing, deforestation, lack of water, and increased disease transmission . Again, it appears that this has not been a substantial concern of the Bank in the past, although now there are plans in train with the object that the environmental dimension will be viewed eventually as a routine and integral part of the project appraisal. That is pleasing.

But possibly the most important question one might ask is whether the Bank is sufficiently aware of the need for socio-political reform within developing member countries to ensure that the benefits from economic development projects equitably benefit the communities as a whole. Of course, the question raises the delicate relationship between the Bank as a regional authority and its client members in wanting to see the benefits of economic development broadly spread throughout such communities yet recognising the desirability of respecting internal development goals. The Bank does now appear to be meeting this challenge reasonably well and it wisely looks to influence social change in economic terms. The 1982 annual report of the Bank states:

While the bank recognises that economic growth is the central factor in its development role, it is equally aware that widespread poverty and inequitable income distribution can disrupt and even negate economic gains by leading to social or political instability. The bank aims, therefore, to combine employment creation and poverty reductions with economic efficiency and viability as major objectives in its development project.

Criticism that may have been made of the Bank in relation to this matter in the past therefore appears not now so well founded. However, it is a pity that the Australian Government, in presenting this Bill to the Parliament-a government claiming to be concerned about socio-economic development in developing countries-did not discuss this matter. The Bank's strategy since the mid-1970s appears to have been, firstly, to concentrate its concessional lending in the poorer developing member countries; secondly, to emphasise investment in sectors which must benefit the poor, such as small farm agriculture and social infrastructure; thirdly, to identify and design individual projects in such a way that their social impact would be high; and, fourthly, to liberalise its modes of lending in suitable cases.

Superficially, in any event, it appears to be matching its rhetoric with action . For example, during 1982, 98 per cent of the Bank's $US547m in ADF lending went to the poorest countries, to Bangladesh, Burma, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Bank finance projects for agriculture and rural development-where it can be best argued that project benefits go directly to the poor, excluding agro- industry-received 34 per cent of the total bank lending in that year. However, it is interesting to note that there was a marked decline in the share of lending for social infrastructure projects. This amounted to about 10 per cent of total lending compared with about 22 per cent in 1981. One might have thought that the Hawke Government would have attempted to explain this surprise to the Parliament. The Bank's explanation is that the figure should be read in conjunction with the sharp 60 per cent increase in bank lending to this sector in 1981. In 1982, however, the Bank made only four loans in the water supply and sanitation sector. One might have expected more. Also, in 1982, in supporting rural health service projects, only two projects were approved. Again, the number appears low. Perhaps it indicates that the Bank is finding difficulty in identifying the role of socio-economic development with economic development. The Bank will argue that its road improvement projects will provide considerable indirect benefit in access to numerous rural areas which are at present inaccessible. The Bank in its 1982 annual report states:
These roads will provide outlets for small holder farm produce, decrease the cost agricultural inputs and allow greater mobility to people living in the project area.

However, this raises the allegations that Australian aid projects are facing in the Philippines of being first used to reinforce the political colour of the incumbent regime. This is a matter to which the ADB will have to give its attention. But at least the Bank does appear to be aware of and wrestling with the inherent priority conflicts in this regard. Its recent study 'The Bank's Operational Priorities and Plans for the 1980s', indicates a growing enhancement of the Bank's role in reducing poverty. That study provides:

First the bank's poverty reducing and employment creating efforts must not be confined to agriculture and social infrastructure projects, but should be incorported, wherever feasible, into projects in other sectors such as development banks and transport and communications. Second, close attention must be paid-especially in projects addressed to the needs of the poor-to sociological and cultural factors and, most importantly, to institution building to correct administrative and management deficiencies. Third, poverty issues should be made an important part of the bank's policy dialogue with its DMCs.
In summary, the bank's objects should be to support an appropriate blend of growth, employment creation and poverty alleviation throughout its broad range of development activities.

No one disputes that the Bank does not and cannot play a worthwhile role in financing economic development projects, but at a more difficult level as to how its funding is affecting social and environmental change, it appears that, at least, the Bank is recognising its responsibility in these areas and making real efforts. Its post-evaluation of projects appears to have been upgraded and is emerging as an important management tool for the future. The fact that in 1982 some 123 loan and technical assistance projects in 21 DMCs were reviewed to assess their environmental impact should be recognised.

But the Australian Government should recognise also that difficulties exist for the future, some of which I mentioned last year. I am sure, for example, that the Senate would like to know the attitude of this Government to the ADB making loans to Vietnam. As I understand it, the ADB's position remains that conditions in the country do not provide a reasonable basis for new lending or for a revival of earlier projects. Does the Australian Government intend to take any action within the ADB to review that policy? Similarly, loans to Afghanistan were stopped with the Soviet intervention in 1979. As I said last year, that policy which was justified on safety reasons, conveniently fits American foreign policy. What is the Australian Government's attitude to that? India has indicated its intention in the future to resume soft loan borrowing which could rapidly exhaust the ADF. What is the Australian Government's attitude to that proposal? What is the Australian Government's attitude to China becoming a member of the Bank? If it does, what is Australia's attitude to the continuing membership of Taiwan? I remind the Senate that China appears to have unofficially applied for membership, but on the basis that Taiwan is expelled. The United States has supported China's admission but not the expulsion of Taiwan. I, and I am sure the Senate, would like to know of the Australian Government's position on that question. Is the Australian Government aware that the ADF is now virtually dependent on Japan, which some commentators argue suits Japan's economic regional strategies? Does the Australian Government, therefore, support or advocate the broadening of the base of support of the Bank and the fund?

These are just some of the questions which, at least some, and, I believe, most in this Senate would have appreciated being addressed by the Government which claims in the Minister's second reading speech to attach particular priority to the needs of developing countries within our region. Some information on the Australian staff of the Bank, with its relationship with the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and with other bilateral and multilateral agencies , the suitability of the Bank's head office remaining in the Philippines in view of current domestic stress and the Bank's plans for a regional office in the South Pacific are just a few of many other questions which the Senate could reasonably have expected to be discussed in the speech introducing this Bill. Therefore, in welcoming the Bill and in expressing support for the Bank and its work, might I also register some disappointment at the somewhat shallow contribution to the debate that is provided by the Minister's speech.

I have time to make only a few comments with regard to the two remaining Bills. To talk, on the one hand, of the regional Bank, the ADB and, on the other hand, of the Bretton Woods structures, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, is really to talk of chalk and cheese, simply looking at size alone. The authorised capital of the World Bank is about $71 billion. For its soft-arm window the latest replenishment was $12 billion. The IMF has a quota of $90 billion compared with the Asian Development Bank which has just doubled its capital to $16.3 billion, while the replenishment of the ADF totalled $4.1 billion. Not only their size but also their roles are very different. One might have argued that really they should have been dealt with separately. All that is in common is the cooling of the United States to both, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank and more specifically, to the soft loan facilities of each, the International Development Association and the ADF. Also in common is the cursory way in which the Government has treated both in this debate, which unfortunately reflects the speeches made by Ministers Hurford and Keating at the annual meeting of the Board of Governors of the Asian Development Bank and the annual meeting of the IMF respectively this year. Unfortunately, neither appears to provide an in-depth analysis of the problems facing each and Australia's proposals for their solution. This can be compared with contributions of Ministers from other countries who addressed these bodies at such annual general meetings. Really, we know little of this Government's attitude to the problems facing the Bretton Woods institutions or the institutions in themselves.

I remind the Senate that the World Bank-IMF combination now is concerned with the welfare of over three-quarters of the world's population. Never has there been a greater need for internationalism. Equally, never has there been a greater opportunity for the Bretton Woods institutions to contribute to the benefit of this massive section of the world community. But what has been a great disappointment to some of us has been that in the face of such a challenge and in response to temporary domestic economic pressures we have been witnessing a withdrawal from internationalism. As was put by the Far Eastern Economic Review in September this year:

The need for statesmanship rather than narrow politicking has probably never been greater in the sphere of the international economy. So much has been achieved there since the war-and so much stands to be lost now or thrown away.

The interdependence of the world economy can be shown no better than in the economic relationship between the United States and the Third World. During the 1970s, annual trade between the United States and the developing world grew from about $11 billion to $82 billion, to the extent that such countries now purchase about 40 per cent of United States exports. In addition, such countries now supply about 44 per cent of United States imports. One would have thought, therefore, that the importance of continued Third World development to the United States would be self-evident and the importance of the World Bank in contributing to Third World development, particularly with finance in relating to infrastructure growth, roads, bridges and dams that provide the economic backbone to developing nations would be obvious. Equally obvious, one would have thought, would have been the importance of a body such as the IMF to endorse and monitor responsible economic policies.

What, of course, has happened is that Western industrial nations including Australia, have been unable to grasp the competitive challenge posed by Japan and the Asian newly industrialising countries such as South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore, most, interestingly, with conscientiously planned economies helped by agencies such as the World Bank. Western industrialised nations have lacked the flexibility to compete in a relatively open world trading environment . In part, the response has been pressures against foreign development aid. Snubs administered to the United States by the emergence of Soviet client states in Africa and elsewhere and actions such as India's balancing act between the United States and the Soviet Union led to pressure, particularly on the United States, to curb its contribution to apolitical multilateral funding organisations. Notwithstanding that the IDA came into being from a United States Treasury proposal in 1959 reflecting, amongst other things, a 'growing feeling that aid should be channelled through multilateral agencies so that it would be less political and more effective in promoting development'. But, it is interesting that, from being out in the cold, suddenly with the need to rescue the Latin American debt crisis and bail out the United States banks, the importance of the IMF has again been recognised. The World Bank, however, remains out of favour but one suspects that its benefits will become more obvious when development stalls. These bodies are not most desirably seen as rescue organisations but rather as bodies able to make a positive future contribution to Third World economic development. I would have liked to have heard this Government dispel the widely held fears that World Bank activities in developing countries displace private sector initiatives. The evidence would suggest that without the World Bank and the IMF the environment in most Third World countries would be much less attractive to multinational companies and commercial banks.

I would have liked to have heard this Government dispel the concern-in fact, it is the commonly held view-that the rate of return on projects supported by the Bank is low. According to a 1982 United States Department of Treasury study the rate of return is 15 to 20 per cent. I would have liked to have heard an assessment of the role the IDA has played in the economic development of India and the potential it could now play, if it were adequately funded, in the development prospects of China. A unique opportunity exists for the Western world to support the fundamental reorientation of China's development strategy taking place, for which China is seeking World Bank support. I would have thought it helpful to point out to the Australian public that 37 per cent of IDA loans now go towards financing agricultural and rural development projects, thus stressing poverty alleviation and raising the productivity of small farmers. One suspects that the United States now believes this to be a wrong direction and that the traditional emphasis should have remained on basic infrastructure as essential prerequisites to development. The Australian Government's view regrettably we do not know.

These are just some of the questions that I would have liked to have addressed in this debate. It might have been too much to expect an analysis of some of the proposals for reform of the Bretton Woods institutions that are currently being floated but at least I believe we could have reasonably expected an assessment of these institutions, the difficulties they are presently encountering and the contribution they can continue to make. In conclusion, at least in bringing these Bills forward the Government is recognisng the importance of multilateral institutions and multilateral solutions to regional and world economic problems. This was a view which of course was firmly held by the previous Government and it is a view which I applaud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the International Development Association (Special Contribution) Bill, the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase) Bill and the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill. The first authorises a special contribution to the International Development Association; the second increases Australia's quota to the International Monetary Fund; and the third provides for an additional subscription to the Asian Development Bank. The International Monetary Fund was an outcome of the 1944 Bretton Woods conference. It essentially provides support funding while its associate institution, the World Bank, specialises in the provision of loans for developmental projects. Prior to its establishment in 1961 it was thought desirable to have an institution such as the International Development Association to make grants rather than loans. But it has emerged as a lender of long term loans at artificially low interest rates. It is acknowledged as being one of the more successful instruments of assisting the low income countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that these developing countries face are fourfold-firstly, their low generation of income per capita; secondly, their high population growth rates; thirdly, their low level of savings; and, fourthly, generally their poor natural resources-hence the need for foreign capital and assistance. But the benefits of private enterprise investment in such regions are very marginal because of the slow rate of maturity of the benefits from investment, as investment in such things as health, education and nutrition do not provide yields or benefits which are quickly or readily converted into hard currency or into exports. Hence the contribution of the International Development Association has been quite valuable. Its lending criteria are that the recipient country should have a per capita income below a certain level and also that the country should have difficulty in obtaining access to normal borrowings. The third institution, the Asian Development Bank, emerged later-in 1966 in fact-in response to dissatisfaction at the lending patterns generally of institutions such as the World Bank, which tended to be more involved in infrastructure finance than in agriculture or in the special needs of Asia.

Tonight I wish to draw attention to the reasons why such an increase in funding for these three institutions is necessary. In doing so I will concentrate on three related problems that our world is now facing: Firstly, there are the trade imbalances between the developed and the developing countries; secondly, there are the effects of the international recession; and, thirdly, there are the international debt and the role of financial institutions. At the meeting of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, UNCTAD VI, which was held in Belgrade in June this year, there was a difference of opinion as to the ways in which the developed and the developing countries saw the causes of the global recession. Parliaments of the world I believe do have an important role to play in the resolution of debt and in the securing of a stronger economic world. Parliamentarians must also be conscious of the fact that decisions taken in one country are rarely isolated from those in other countries. Politics aside , Australia for its part I hope will continue to play a constructive role in the development of UNCTAD's work program and its future activities in the financing of appropriate institutions.

I have a few comments to make on trade imbalances. Individual countries must collectively unite and search for solutions to the international crisis. Nations are increasingly recognising that each is becoming dependent on the world community-a sick part in one sector has repercussions in other parts. Australia as a major trading nation has a vested interest in assisting quick recovery from this world recession. Sixty-five developing countries receive 60 per cent of their revenue from the export of commodities as such. One of the chief characteristics of this downturn in economic activity includes this low commodity crisis. But other factors are contributing, such as the intensification of protectionist pressures within the developing countries and inflation. To inflation I would also add an associative factor called social inflation. This is a new term but it is very significant because social inflation refers to the struggle of the disadvantaged in such countries to share in development.

High interest rates are another problem. A one per cent increase in interest rates costs developing countries $US4 billion per year, so interest rates and the rise or fall of interest rates can have a traumatic effect on the problems affecting developing countries. Another factor is increases in prices of oil and manufactured goods. Another is the problem of heavy debt structures which have been aggravated by problems in capacity to pay and in the shortness of the term to maturity of loans. Of course this capacity to pay has been aggravated by receipt of low commodity prices. Another factor is high unemployment, particularly since the Second World War, with masses of unskilled who are left at the bottom of what can be termed the social structure, missing out on the fruits of development. There has been limited or negative productive growth. All these factors and more manifest themselves in issues such as disturbance to world trade, decreases in economic exchanges, restricted investment growth and the problems of debt and balance of payments deficits.

International peace cannot be sustained while the economic position in the developing countries continues to deteriorate. Regrettably, the gap between rich and poor is widening. Economic development cannot be achieved without peace. Many of our Asian neighbours experience border stresses and incursions by belligerent powers. The raising of their living standards under such circumstances is quite remarkable and is to their credit. I point to countries such as Korea, Thailand, Malaysia and so on. The growth in their manufactured products-these newly emerging economic miracles-is creating problems and challenges for Australia.

Another factor of great significance is the arms race. This must be stopped in the interest of economic development and world harmony. I think it is of significance that even some of the oil producing countries are suffering as a result of decreased oil volume and decreased prices. They have some debt problems associated not only with decreased oil prices but also increased costs of imported manufactured goods. Countries that are affected in this way include Mexico, Nigeria and Venezuela. They are all producers whose credit ratings are now very marginal because of excessive borrowings and the problems of commodity price reductions and import cost inflation. We in Australia are justifiably complaining about problems which have been inflicted on our nation as a result of the international recession but those difficulties are but a whimper compared with some of the intolerable sufferings of some of the people in the Third World where millions are afflicted by an increase in malnutrition and a deterioration of health standards.

The big problem we are facing at the moment is the management of this huge debt problem. In fact the foreign debt of developing countries now exceeds $650 billion, and it is growing daily. The impact has forced debt countries to cancel essential development programs and, all too frequently, to lower standards of living. Individual countries cannot move unilaterally in, say, holding back raw materials in an endeavour to increase prices or, at the other end of the spectrum, to lower protection to the detriment of their own work forces in situations of gross over supply and limited demand. It is important that, through appropriate institutions, they act in concert. I believe it is regrettable that around the world most governments have not reached the target of 0.7 per cent of their gross national product for development aid. There appears to be a high degree of irresponsibility by some leaders who tend to over -borrow and to commit their countries to unacceptable levels of indebtedness. On the other hand, I believe that institutions which recklessly lend, following what might be referred to as the 'herd' instinct, are also equally culpable. The risk of a major international default is high. The world has been warned of the domino effect of a combination of significant countries failing at the same time .

We are all aware of the debt problems of Mexico, Brazil, Poland, Yugoslavia, Romania, Equador, Chile, Cuba and Uruguay. But more recently, since August, and closer to home, a new emergency has spilled over into the Asian region. The Philippines is experiencing civil unrest. This has caused a drop in exports and the country is experiencing capital withdrawals. The interdependence of nations is reflected in the Philippines situation. This problem is now indirectly causing some difficulties to our close neighbour Indonesia. It is experiencing a new problem, a fall in its credit rating and an increase in the cost of money that it must pay for its borrowings. With three bank failures each week not uncommon in the United States, the problem of debt is indeed severe. Existing international bodies have been unable to meet the requirements for world development and have been unable to meet this crisis. Governments must seek to arrive at establishing a framework for negotiations between debtors and creditors, with interest rates reduced and maturities increased. Fortunately, much has been achieved to avoid a crisis by unprecedented co-operation among banks, governments and international agencies.

What are the solutions? Some leading economists and politicians have called for a new economic order to ensure economic justice, to facilitate technological transfers, to improve dialogue and co-operation, to facilitate trade balances and to establish financial institutions appropriate to the needs, especially of the developing countries. Progress will indeed be slow while the world lives under a cloud of an unprecedented build up of arms and growing trouble spots around the world, encouraged by the widening mistrust between the super-powers. Nations naturally turn to UNCTAD as an organisation capable of finding solutions to world structural and trading problems. Developing countries themselves, for their own part, I believe, have a role to play in the control of demographic growth, respect for the rights of minorities, sound management resources and control of inflation. Clearly, countries, both developed and developing, will not be able to avoid careful domestic management involving difficult decisions in order to take advantage of the recovery that now seems to be under way in some industrialised countries. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
