INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., in accordance with sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to detain the Senate for very long, but I wish to raise on the adjournment a matter I raised with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by letter dated 6 July this year. On the day before that, I had representations from a young man and a young woman who had recently returned to Australia from India and Sri Lanka. That young man and young woman put a series of bits of paper in front of me, some of which were papers which had been forwarded to the Prime Minister. They told me a story about their suspicions and concerns about international drug activities and other criminal activities. They told me a story about their view that the Australian consular officials had not properly responded to their requests for assistance and, indeed, had behaved in a way which put them at risk. They told me that they were not satisfied with the way in which the information they were trying to provide to government was being received, and they were also concerned about a personal matter, namely, the recovery of a yacht in which they had sailed from Australia to the port of Cochin.

SPEECH.PARA: In putting these matters down on the adjournment, I should like just to mention that normally when people make representations of this sort to me I would not make them public. Apart from anything else, they go possibly to the personal security of the people concerned as well as to their privacy. In this case, however, the people who came to see me have made an effort to interest a range of authorities in the matters about which they are concerned, and they have, in trying to follow this through, used the Freedom of Information Act to recover some of the papers which have gone in. Among other things, they have published the letter which I wrote to the Prime Minister on 6 July. So the matter has ceased to be one of great privacy and I raise it because I have not had a response from the Prime Minister, or in any sense a substantive response, and I am concerned as to how this matter has been handled. I should like to read the letter I wrote on 6 July, which will put more shortly than if I were to keep chatting about them the matters that I raised with the Prime Minister. The letter reads:

I have received representations from Mr Brian Maxwell Milgate and Ms Alison McGuinness relating to matters which have been dealt with by the Department of Foreign Affairs in India and Sri Lanka and which touch on allegations of illegal activities centred in Cochin.
Ms McGuinness has written to you-
that is, to the Prime Minister-

from Colombo on 24 June. A number of other documents have been submitted by them jointly to the Department of Foreign Affairs. The specific matter which has been raised with me is to enquire what they might expect to be done by the Department to help them recover their assets from Cochin and in particular, the yacht '' Tiger Rag''. I am raising the matter with you rather than the Minister for Foreign Affairs because you are already involved and because I think a number of your Ministers should be concerned about the matters raised.

Both Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness have confirmed that they are happy to provide detailed information to the police or any departmental official and have also advised me that they are making material available to Interpol on the drug trade through Cochin. In light of the sorry history of drug investigations and the frequent allegations of corruption and ineptitude I am concerned that they have an opportunity to provide all relevant information to a representative of your administration who can be relied upon to follow the matters through in an appropriate manner. I would be grateful, therefore, if you would through the appropriate Ministers, arrange for me to be advised:
(a) what assistance, if any, is available to them with respect to the recovery of their property;
(b) what is the appropriate body or person to whom they should provide information within Australia;
(c) whether the complaints about the assistance received by them so far are justified.

In retrospect, I suppose that in that letter there is a heavier emphasis on the recovery of their property than might have appeared warranted in the light of the very wide allegations they made and their suspicions of international drug smuggling, and so on. Clearly I was referring all those matters to the Prime Minister, and he had received other detailed information. The only response I have had was a letter dated 22 July, which was signed by Mr Lionel Bowen, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, in these terms:
The Prime Minister has asked me to reply to your letter of 6 July 1983 on behalf of Mr B. M. Milgate and Ms A. McGuinness, concerning the recovery of their yacht 'Tiger Rag' from Cochin.

Mr Milgate's and Ms McGuinness' letter to the Prime Minister was drawn to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Bill Hayden. I have, therefore, forwarded your representations to Mr Hayden with a request that he co -ordinate a reply to you on behalf of the Government.
Yours sincerely.

Last week in Perth a rather dramatic story appeared in a newspaper known as the Western Mail. That referred to Western Australian links in a spy and drugs riddle and to an allegation that there had been a seizure of a $250m cargo of hashish off the United States coast. Summarising the story, it suggested that this followed the arrest of a boat which had been identified in the material provided to me and to the Government by the couple whose names I have mentioned. The article indicates that the young couple have been pretty active in trying to follow it up, and on their account they have been in communication with authorities both within Australia and internationally. They had been told that the information they gave had been passed on to the Australian Federal Police and they had understood that it would be sent internationally. Because there was no response from the authorities in Australia, they sent details of their claims to drug enforcement agencies in the United States, Britain and France. Over the recent weeks they claim that the United States Coastguard Service has been in touch with them, obtaining from them the details that they have been able to provide. They are somewhat puzzled by that in the light of the fact that all of these details have been in the hands of government authorities for some time.

I do not expect the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to have a full response for me, but I should like to make quite clear what my concern is in raising this matter. This couple were quite worried enough about their personal safety to change their names on their return to Western Australia . As I indicated to them, I had no way of telling whether their story was true or false. I had no means of investigating the quite detailed allegations they made. My real concern, quite apart from the recovery of their personal possessions, was to try to ensure that some appropriate authority would take charge of the information they provided and follow it through in a proper manner .

As I said in my letter to the Prime Minister-this is in no sense a crack at the Government, which has only recently become the Government of Australia-we do not have a very good record of investigation in these areas. We are all familiar with some of the problems which have arisen. It is a matter of concern to me that when people believe that they have come across significant criminal activities, there ought to be some source to which they can go with confidence to have these matters followed up. In this case it may seem a little extreme to go to the Prime Minister, but it seemed to me that since the matter had already been put in his hands it was reasonable to send my correspondence to him and ask him to delegate it to some appropriate authority. I am not very impressed by the somewhat perfunctory reply I have had to date.

I seek an assurance from the Government that these matters have been dealt with properly. I ask also that, if possible, it be indicated just what has been done to follow up these allegations. I place much greater emphasis on that now than on this question of the recovery of property. We have had great deal of talk in this Parliament and elsewhere about the corruption of Australian society. Much of what these people were reporting on was taking place outside Australia, but I am concerned about whether some proper action was taken. If such action was taken, I would like to know what it was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to raise two matters. The first relates to a document which quite fortuitously came into my hands only about an hour ago, quite by accident. It is a staff circular of the Department of the Senate. It is circular No. 46 of 1983 and is entitled 'Structure of Offices'. Amongst other things, it says that following a decision by the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee to restructure the Department into various offices certain positions will be advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, the Canberra Times and the Australian. That did not mean much to me except that I noticed under the heading 'Committee Office' mention was made of the Clerk of Committees, Class 11. That rang a bell, so I made a few inquiries. It turns out that Clerk of Committees is no doubt the correct title for the secretaries of standing committees, but probably one that is never used in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: On making a few phone calls to other chairmen of Senate standing committees, I discovered that they had not been informed of this decision made somewhere within the Department to advertise the position of secretaries to their committees. The circular referred to is dated 1 November 1983, so that is well over two weeks ago. It is a staff circular and chairmen of committees have not even been given the courtesy of a communication of this proposal, which is quite a dramatic one. What was particularly galling for me as Chairman, amongst others , of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was to turn the page to the heading 'Procedure Office' and find mention of Clerk of Committees, Class 11. I am informed that that is a reference to the secretaries of the Senate Standing Comittee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I say that it is particularly galling, Mr President, because as you will know, on the resumption of the Budget session, at the first meeting of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on 24 August 1983 it was resolved:

. . . that the Chairman write to the President of the Senate and request that he make immediate arrangements for the appointment of a permanent Secretary to the Committee, such arrangements to include provision for external advertising and consultation with the Chairman during the final selection process.
In terms of that resolution I wrote to you, Mr President, and received a reply dated 29 August, the relevant part of which was:

In this regard, it is relevant that Dr Uhr applied for and accepted the transfer on the basis that it is temporary. It was because of the temporary nature of the transfer that it was advertised only within the Senate Department, and the selection made from officers who applied on that basis.

In other words, the indication from your office, Mr President, was that it was impossible to countenance the advertising of this particular position, even though it was the desire of the Committee that that be done. Having received that reply on 7 September, in lieu of a resolution, it was recorded in the minutes, amongst other things, that:

The Chairman undertook to have further discussion with the President and to request that the position of Committee Secretary be resolved (as outlined in the Chairman's letter of 24 August 1983) at the end of the current period of sittings.

Within my previous letter, there was a proviso for advertising the position. Quite by chance, as I say, we came across a circular which contains a matter of interest to all Senate committee chairmen. It is of particular interest to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee as it believes that, as with the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, the secretary's position ought to be advertised. Indeed, we have a preference for that advertisement to include a requirement of legal qualifications, but that is by the way. I raise the matter as one wishing to seek information as to how it was that that staff circular went out without the chairmen of the various committees being informed of this quite unusual and novel procedure.

I raise very briefly a separate matter relating to some approaches that have been made to me in relation to incorporation within the Australian Capital Territory of certain associations. Voluntary associations, as honourable senators know, in most jurisdictions can apply for incorporation under various statutes or ordinances. Once that is done there becomes available to them the opportunity to take advantage of various provisions of the law. Therefore, the various documents that have to be filled in in order for them to attain that status are quite important. Because one is dealing with voluntary associations, perhaps without legal or other expertise available to them, it is important that the various forms with which they have to deal be in a very clear and easily understood form. In relation to these matters it has been brought to my attention by some voluntary associations within the Australian Capital Territory that the old forms are well out of date. It is their understanding that new forms have been drafted and that sample copies are being prepared within the particular division responsible for drafting these matters within the Attorney- General's Department. I believe that division must be the corporate affairs division.

The necessity of these new forms is shown by the fact that at the present moment the associations are dealing with forms which are xeroxed, totally inadequate and misleading as to the existence of provisions and forms which are no longer part of the law. It is understood that these forms were drafted as early as February this year, but no steps have been taken to promulgate them or to bring them into the public arena for use by these voluntary associations. I certainly wish to be followed up the question of who within the bureaucracy is responsible for this inordinate delay which is causing difficulty to some 200 or 300 such associations which are registered every year. It seems to me that it is something which ought to be attended to expeditiously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was both interested and concerned to hear what Senator Tate had to say in relation to the advertising of Senate committee positions. It had been my understanding that under the two preceding Presidents there had been established in the Senate a practice-established, I thought beyond any doubt-that in relation to appointment of committee staff, and in particular, committee secretaries, that there would at all times be consultation with the chairman of the committee who would as necessary report to the committee, and that there would not be the situation which had been the source of considerable irritation over a period of time of people finding that appointments and rearrangements had been made without their knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: I am conscious of and acknowledge the point made that there is a necessity to ensure that there is not politicisation of the staff of the committees of the Parliament. However, opposed to that there is also a need, which I thought had been determined, to ensure that there is consultation. I recall that when the appointment of the secretary of the committee of which I was chairman during the preceding parliament-the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations-was being arranged, when out of some 80 applicants it had got to a final five or so, I was present at the interview of the final five and was able to report to the Committee in relation to that. Whilst I did not at any time suggest that the Chairman of the Committee or the Committee as a whole should select and appoint, there should be consultation and it was my understanding that that would happen. I can only say that that was the view of the chairmen of all of the standing committees. It was a unanimous view, a view which I understood was accepted and which I understood was put into practice. It would be regrettable if that did not continue, and if any of the correspondence passed in relation to that matter is of any assistance in relation to this matter, then I would be happy to seek the approval of those whom I represented when I was involved in the correspondence to make it available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am not able to offer any enlightenment on the matters raised by Senator Tate and Senator Peter Rae but Senator Chaney did advise me of his intention to raise a matter relating to Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness. I have been able to obtain some information, not all of which I think thoroughly deals with the concerns which Senator Chaney expressed. There are really two issues- first, the way representations concerning narcotics made by Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness to Australian consular officials in India and Sri Lanka were handled, and secondly, the disposal of their property including the yacht which bore the name Tiger Rag.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the first matter, I am advised that when complaints or information were passed by Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness to the consular officials in India and Sri Lanka it was decided by the Department of Foreign Affairs that the matter should be independently investigated by a senior officer who had no responsibilities in the consular area of the Department. In the course of this investigation, an officer subsequently flew to Perth to give Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness the opportunity to relate their story and their complaints in the fullest possible manner. At the end of a six-hour interview they both acknowledged that they had been given every opportunity to present their case. The investigation into this matter has now concluded and it has been determined that on no occasion did consular officials in India and Sri Lanka dismiss any written or verbal allegations that the complainants made concerning narcotics intelligence and on no occasion did they fail to pass on these allegations fully and promptly to the appropriate Australian and Indian authorities. The Department of Foreign Affairs has been passing promptly to the Australian Federal Police all allegations and information relating to narcotics that it has received since Ms McGuinness first contacted the Australian Consulate in Bombay on 21 April this year. Similarly, I am advised that there is no indication that Australian consular officials overseas rendered any less than the full consular support called for under the circumstances.

I think that in relation to that matter Senator Chaney really couched his concern in terms of the need for an apparently appropriate authority to take charge in respect of the allegations or complaints made by these two people. On the basis of the information I have at this moment, it appears that as far as the Department of Foreign Affairs is concerned an independent officer was appointed to investigate the matter and on the basis of the instructions I have, all the complaints were conveyed immediately to the Australian Federal Police. I do not know what happened to them after that; I have no information about it. It may be that the Australian Federal Police was in touch with the United States authorities. It may be that the defects were rather in the failure of somebody from the Australian Federal Police or elsewhere to speak to the two complainants as the United States Coastguard did, and maybe it goes no further than that. If further information is sought on that aspect I will certainly endeavour to obtain it. Once again, it may be a question of the Australian Federal Police desiring to maintain anonymity in respect of any discussions it might have had with international authorities.

On the question of the yacht, the Tiger Rag, I am advised that it was first explained to Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness while they were still in India that the Australian Government is unable to provide physical protection for Australians and their property abroad. That remains the province of local authorities. However, Australian officials did make such inquiries and representations on behalf of the two concerned to the local authorities as were appropriate. I am advised that the couple entered into a private commercial arrangement with a boatshed in Cochin for the repair of the yacht, the Tiger Rag , and any dispute arising from this arrangement has to be settled by recourse to local law. I am further advised that included in a folder of papers addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), Department of Foreign Affairs officials and Ms McGuinness's father was a copy of a letter signed jointly by Milgate and McGuinness, undated and addressed to the Foreign Affairs Department, which stated, inter alia:
We suggest that 'Tiger Rag' can be scrapped and the remainder of our assets returned to Australia . . .
In a further letter dated 13 June 1983 addressed to a Mr M. A. Menon, Superintendent of Intelligence, Customs Branch, Willingdon Island, Cochin, Mr Brian Milgate states:

. . . this letter will give the authority and cover the necessary permissions regarding 'Tiger Rag' and her equipment under seizure by Customs Department. The Australian Government has been advised that 'Tiger Rag' is to be scrapped where she is.

As far as Foreign Affairs officials can determine, this decision was made quite voluntarily by Mr Milgate and Ms McGuinness. So in respect of the yacht there are two items of correspondence-one addressed to the Foreign Affairs Department and undated, including the comment which I quoted, that Tiger Rag be scrapped and the remainder of the assets returned to Australia and, in corroboration of that, another letter dated 13 June 1983 in which the Superintendent of Intelligence at Customs House in Cochin is advised that this decision in the undated letter has already been communicated to the Australian authorities and that it is the intention of the owners that the boat be scrapped where she is.

That is the only information with which I am able to assist Senator Chaney at this stage. I share his concern, as I think every responsible citizen would, that these two people had gone to the lengths of changing their names and so on in order to avoid any possible victimisation as a result of telling their story, and that there did seem to be a greater courtesy in the United States Coastguard than perhaps in the appropriate Australian authorities, though that may not necessarily be a fair judgment on what took place. As I have indicated, Senator Chaney indeed said that in his view now the question of the recovery of property was subordinate to those other matters and I think the material which I have been able to give regarding the recovery of property issue is fairly conclusive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you follow up whether any effective action was taken with respect to the allegations about drugs and so on, because that is not at all apparent?
—The honourable senator will appreciate that it may be one of those spooky areas where it is intended to be secret.
—But we need to know and you need to know, I think, whether it just ran into the sand or was dealt with in a proper way.

—I think that the Department of Foreign Affairs has seen that it was dealt with as expeditiously as possible and so on. But I will follow up the remaining area of concern and see whether I can obtain the appropriate answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the following anomalies exist under the Income Tax Assessment Act:
(a) the maximum penalty for failure to keep sufficient records (section 262A(1) ) is $200 irrespective of the level of taxable income;

(b) the maximum penalty for failure to lodge a return is $200 (section 223) whereas the maximum penalty for omitting income is double the tax payable on omitted income section 226(2)), which leads to a situation, where taxable income is high, in which taxpayers aware of the provisions might deliberately court prosecution under section 223 so as to avoid prosecution under section 226(2) in respect of the same matter;

(c) the maximim penalty for failure to deduct withholding tax is $200 (section 221ZL(4A)) whereas the maximum penalty for failure to remit such tax which has been deducted is $1,000 or 6 months imprisonment (section 221ZN(2)), which means that taxpayers face a heavier penalty for deducting it in the first place;

(d) penalties are expressed in fixed dollar terms and these are likely to lose their signifiance over time unless they are adjusted to take account of inflation, and such penalties are unlikely to differentiate adquately between less serious and very serious offences; and

(e) section 226(2) imposes a penalty where a taxpayer, inter alia, 'includes in his return as a deduction expenditure incurred by him in excess of the amount actually incurred' and that the taxpayer would be liable for penalty only if he claimed a deduction in excess of expenditure actually incurred although he would not incur a penalty if he claimed a non-allowable deduction.
(2) What action has the Government taken to assess and eradicate any such anomalies.

(3) Would penalties expressed as a percentage of, for example, the delinquent tax, and not in fixed dollar terms as indicated in 1(d) above, differentiate between different offences and maintain their real impact over time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government realises that, with the passage of time, some of the penalties contained in taxation laws have lost their effectiveness. The Government expects to receive the results of a general review of the whole range of taxation penalties soon. When that is received the Government will give careful consideration to proposals for upgrading relevant penalty provisions.

(3) Yes, but a number of penalties prescribed in the taxation laws are already expressed as a monetary amount plus a percentage of the tax avoided. For instance the penalty prescribed for the offence of making a false return or statement is a maximum fine of $200 together with a sum not exceeding double the tax attempted to be avoided.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many prosecutions under section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act are currently before the courts.
(2) How many prosecutions have been considered under the above section.
(3) How many have not been proceeded with because of the inadequacy of the section.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The strict answer to each of the honourable senator's questions is 'nil' as section 260 does not create an offence. The following information is provided, however, with a view to assisting the honourable senator.

Section 260 is a general anti-avoidance provision. The section makes void, as against the Commissioner, any contract, agreement, or arrangement that has the purpose or effect of avoiding the liability of a person to pay tax. The section does not apply to any contract, agreement or arrangement made or entered into after 27 May 1981. Part IVA of the Act contains the general anti-avoidance provisions that apply to schemes entered into after that date.

Section 260 was construed by courts as not affecting the view expressed by the House of Lords in Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster that ' every man is entitled if he can to order his affairs so as that the tax attaching under the appropriate Act is less than it otherwise would be.' As a consequence, the section has not frequently been found to justify contested assessments. The Commissioner's reliance on the section has been recently upheld by the Supreme Court of Western Australia in relation to a scheme involving the sale of a medical practice to unit trusts (Watson v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation 83 ATC 4336 and Gulland v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation 83 ATC 4352 ).

I have been advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that there are no statistics relating to the number of matters in which the assessor relied upon section 260 in making the assessment or in respect of which an assessment might have been issued for a greater amount had the courts given section 260 a wider field of operation.

He estimates that there are currently 4000 cases subject to litigation before the courts or the taxation boards of review where the nature of the issues in dispute could conceivably lead to the court or board being asked to consider the application of section 260. It is not possible to provide figures in relation to the number of these cases in which the Commissioner will in fact rely upon section 260 to support the assessments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Treasurer refer on 30 May 1983 to a period of service being apportioned in order to determine that part of the proceeds of superannuation benefits falling after 30 June 1983 which is subject to the new 'super tax' arrangements.

(2) Is the Treasurer aware that many superannuation schemes have periods of qualifying service which are pre-conditions to entitlements and in which partial or no benefits may accrue and that only after the completion of that pre- entitlement period does the superannuation benefit accrue to the employee; if so , and given these circumstances, will the starting date for the period of calculation of the period of service prior to 30 June 1983 be the date of the qualifying service or the entitlement date.
(3) Will the starting date apply from 30 June 1983 or from the entitlement date , for those persons still serving the qualifying period as at 30 June 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In my statement of 7 August 1983 I announced that the basic apportionment rule in relation to employees covered by employer-supported superannuation schemes will be the period, or aggregate of the periods, of employment to which the lump sum relates. Where this includes any period of qualifying employment prior to membership of a superannuation fund it will not be a test that the qualifying period be required by the fund rules. It may also include, in appropriate circumstances, any period of membership of an unsupported fund where there has been a transfer of accruing benefits between superannuation funds of different kinds. In relation to periods after 30 June, it may also include any period during which moneys were held in an approved deposit fund.

In general where, either in the past or the future, an employee has fully preserved entitlements to lump sums when changing jobs or when moving from one fund to another, periods of employment or, where appropriate, membership of a fund and lump sums will both be aggregated when applying the before/after formula. Where none of the lump sum has been preserved, there will be no aggregation of either the amount of that lump sum or the period to which it relates. Where there is partial preservation, and transfer of less than the entire benefit from fund to fund, there will be aggregation with an adjustment related to the unpreserved amount.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are school fund and school council accounts, sporting funds, et cetera associated with schools exempt from the Bank Account Debits Tax Act 1982.
(2) Are school parents and citizens associations, welfare clubs, ethnic parent committees, et cetera which provide for the children's schooling not exempt from this tax; if so, why is this the case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act 1982 exempt from the tax debits to cheque accounts of certain organizations including non-profit schools. Debits to a cheque account in the name of a non-profit school are exempt if they relate to transactions carried out by or on behalf of the association or body which conducts the school and the transactions are wholly and exclusively in furtherance of its objects.
Cheque accounts of school support bodies such as parents and citizens associations, mothers' clubs, ethnic parent committees and similar auxiliary bodies are not exempt from the tax.

Whether cheque accounts in the name of school funds, school councils or sporting funds are within the scope of the exemption for non-profit schools depends on whether the account in question is one operated by the association or body that carries on the school.

The Government will shortly be reviewing the operation of the bank account debits tax. Representations have been received from school support bodies and other non-profit bodies seeking exemption from the tax and these will be carefully considered in the course of the review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australia been criticised in some international forums for its anti- dumping practices; if so, are these practices in contravention of an international code or memorandum of understanding to which Australia is a signatory; if not, then what steps are being taken to rebut any such criticism.
(2) Will the promised 'fast track' anti-dumping arrangements for the steel industry contravene or be in accordance with Australia's international obligations.
(3) When and where will the promised 'fast track' anti-dumping procedures for the steel industry be announced.
(4) Will these 'fast track' arrangements apply to any other industry as well as steel; if so, why; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia is a signatory to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade anti -dumping code. Our anti-dumping legislation and administrative practices accord with the principles contained in that code.

As a code signatory Australia attends meetings of the GATT Anti-Dumping Committee which meets regularly to discuss dumping issues. These meetings provide the opportunity for members to review other countries' implementation of the codes. At such a meeting earlier this year Australia was requested to provide clarification of some aspects of Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act which was amended in 1982. At the next meeting of the Committee, later this month, Australia will formally respond to this request.
(2) The 'fast track' anti-dumping arrangements for steel will not contravene Australia's international obligations.

(3) There is no intention to announce the new 'fast track' anti-dumping procedures in relation to the steel industry. They will be activated by the steel industry authority when it is appointed and following the introduction of the steel industry plan on 1 January 1984.

(4) No. A 'fast track' mechanism is appropriate in the steel industry because of the plan to operate for the industry after 1 January 1984 and in particular because of the involvement of the proposed steel industry authority. These circumstances do not apply for other industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Ardmona, the manufacturers of 'Rippa' fruit juice drinks required to pay sales tax of 22.5 per cent; if so, what is the reason for this sales tax.
(2) Are 100 per cent fruit juices based on imported concentrates free of sales tax.
(3) Does this situation apply to the same products produced locally.
(4) Why does this differential occur.
(5) Will the Government review the situation with a view to removing this anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Express provisions in the sales tax law preclude the disclosure of information about the affairs of individual taxpayers. The sales tax law provides that manufacturers of fruit juice products which do not qualify for exemption are required to pay sales tax at the rate of 20 per cent.

Exemption applies to certain fruit juice products, other than carbonated soft drinks, which are not alcoholic and which consist of specified percentages by volume of juices of Australian fruits or vegetables. A limited range of exemptions also exists for some imported fruit juice products consisting of specified percentages of juices of New Zealand and Papua New Guinea fruits. In the August 1983 Budget the exemption for New Zealand fruit juice products was widened to give effect to Australia's obligations under the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (CER Agreement).

(2) and (3) Generally speaking fruit juice products consisting of 100 per cent fruit juices reconstituted from imported concentrates are not exempt from tax. The only exception occurs in giving effect to the CER Agreement. Some fruit juice products consisting of 100 per cent fruit juices reconstituted from New Zealand concentrates, whether the fruit juice products are manufactured in New Zealand or in Australia, may qualify for exemption.
Fruit juice products produced in Australia and consisting wholly of juices of Australian fruits or vegetables are exempt from sales tax.
(4) and (5) There is not any anomaly in this matter in the sales tax law.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States of America: Deployment of Nuclear Missiles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 October:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs' answer to question with notice ( Hansard, 20 September 1983, p. 820) mean that the Government accepts that deployment and endorses the deployment of Cruise and Pershing missiles.
(2) Has the Government made its own assessment of the situation using Australian intelligence agencies or has the Government relied on a United States assessment of the situation.

(3) Has the Government considered alternative viewpoints such as that provided by the Centre for Defence Information in Washington, a research group staffed by retired senior US military officers, which stated in its publication Defence Monitor (v.XII No. 4, 1983):

The fact of the matter is that the Soviet Union for more than 20 years has been able to devastate all of Western Europe with nuclear weapons just as we have been able to devastate the Soviet Union. The SS20 missile has made no substantial change in the nuclear threat to Europe.
(4) Is the Government aware that the Centre for Defence Information has stated that not only are the Cruise and Pershing missiles unecessary but also that:

The small size and mobility of cruise missiles will make it almost impossible to verify nuclear arms reduction agreements. The similarity between conventional and nuclear armed cruise missiles exacerbates the verification problem. Cruise missiles threaten and end to effective arms control.
(5) What is the Government's assessment of these extremely serious critiques of United States nuclear policy which have been raised by eminently qualified United States military officials.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government does not see a need for it to endorse decisions other countries make for their defence. In this case it understands the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation decision. The Government is strongly committed to progress on disarmament and arms control especially in relation to nuclear weapons. It has repeatedly stated its hope that the superpowers will be able to reach agreements in the START and INF negotiations leading to qualitative restraints and quantitative reductions in arsenals. In the INF negotiations the Government wishes to see a balanced, equitable and verifiable agreement which reduces and ultimately eliminates intermediate-range nuclear missiles on a global basis. It believes that an agreement which led to the elimination of an entire class of nuclear weapons would be a major achievement. The NATO deployments are scheduled to commence in December 1983. Initial preparations for these deployments are well underway. In the event that it is not possible for the United States and the Soviet Union to reach an agreement in the INF negotiations before deployment , the Government accepts that deployments will go ahead to counter the present Soviet advantage in intermediate-range ballistic missiles. Notwithstanding any such development the Government will urge that the superpowers should continue their efforts to reach an agreement on INF.
(2) The Government assesses such issues independently on the basis of all available information and the views of its own advisers.
(3) and (4) Yes.

(5) The Government is aware that debate within NATO over NATO's nuclear weapons strategy is as old as NATO itself. Eminent persons on both sides of the debate have made substantial contributions to it. The views advanced by the Centre for Defense Information have their supporters but constitute only one side of the debate. For example, the Centre's view recorded in the third part of the question that 'the SS20 missile has made no substantial change in the nuclear threat to Europe' is not shared by the sixteen governments that constitute the NATO alliance. It was the Soviet Union's deployment of the SS20 that provoked NATO's response in the form of its decision to modernise intermediate-range nuclear forces through the deployment of cruise and Pershing II missiles in the event that negotiations to limit this class of weapons proved fruitless. Similar considerations apply to the Centre's views on cruise missiles recorded in the fourth part of the question. Cruise missiles constitute only one part of the superpowers' nuclear arsenals. Although it is generally conceded that cruise missiles pose problems of verification, many hold the view that these are not insurmountable. In SALT II for example, it proved possible for the superpowers to agree on arrangements, accepted by both sides, which imposed verifiable limits on air launched cruise missiles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government a plan or projection as to the (a) maintenance; (b) expansion; and (c) reduction of each of the four categories as outlined in Question on Notice No. 440.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The basis of our defence planning is the assessment of our strategic circumstances and objectives. Although the nation presently faces no prospect of military threat, the Government is committed to the maintenance of a capable defence force. In the light of our recently established strategic policy the Government will be reviewing the content and priorities of the Defence Force. This review in no way rests on a desire to cut back on our defence effort. The review will be founded on the conviction that peace-time resources will never be enough to meet all the Defence Force's requirements and therefore only careful analysis of these requirements against the Government's fundamental priorities will permit us to meet our responsibilities to the nation. The Defence Department has been directed to systematically examine our major defence capabilities so that the Government can see the options available to it and make any necessary changes.

The Government's plans for the Permanent Defence Force, the Defence Reserve Forces and the cadets will be founded on this review process. Some decisions have already been taken. Decisions announced in the 1983-84 Budget or since include:
(a) Permanent Defence Force: Reductions in Navy approved terminal strengths during 1983-84 of 450 associated with the phase out of naval fixed wing aviation and the loss of the carrier.
An increase in Air Force terminal strength of 200 during 1983-84 to enable recruitment of extra technical personnel for FA-18 acquisition.
A small reduction in Army terminal strength during 1983-84 of 173 associated with savings arising from internal restructuring.

(b) Defence Reserve Forces: The Government plans to hold the strength of the Army Reserve during 1983-84 at about 30,000, the level set by the previous Government. There will be small increases in the terminal strengths of the Naval Reserve and the Air Force Reserve for 1983-84.

(c) Australian Army Cadet Corps: The Australian Army Cadet Corps will be restructured along the lines of existing Navy and Air Force cadet schemes. Army cadet units will be based at Army Reserve depots rather than at schools. There is no planned reduction in the approved strength of the Army Cadet Corps.
(d) Naval Reserve Cadets and Air Training Corps Cadets. There is no plan to reduce the approved strengths of either the Naval Reserve cadets or the Air Training Corps cadets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June 1983 (Hansard, page 1280), Senator Coates asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a recent advertisement in the Australian Financial Review headed 'Tax Avoidance is alive and well in Australia '? I ask the Minister: Even if the Government has to live with the decision of this House last night to allow $570m of revenue to be lost, will the Government do something to kill the effectiveness of those who continue to rip off the vast majority of Australian taxpayers and who make a living out of encouraging others to do the same? Alternatively, if tax avoidance is no longer alive and well, can the government take action against Dr Clyne for false advertising?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation assures me that he is well aware of the type of tax avoidance advice peddled by Mr Clyne and has expressed confidence that the advocated tax avoidance tactics will prove to be ineffective. Mr Clyne's singular lack of success in his personal attempts to contest actions of the Commissioner before the courts and taxation boards of review are a matter of public record. In this atmosphere I believe that any person who sought to utilise the advice of Mr Clyne to avoid or evade his fair contribution to the revenue would run the very real risk of meeting the full force of the prosecution and penalty provisions of the income tax law.

The Government believes that the most effective way to smash the tax avoidance industry is to ensure that the income tax law is safeguarded against tax avoidance arrangements. Accordingly, the Government announced on 28 April 1983 that it will, as necessary, employ retrospective legislation to ensure that tax sought to be avoided under any blatant tax avoidance scheme that comes to light during our term of office will be collected, irrespective of when the scheme was entered into. This policy will ensure that there will no longer be even the slightest possibility that a newly emerging scheme can have its intended effect. Furthermore, retrospective legislation that it becomes necessary to introduce will, as it applies to schemes entered into after 28 April 1983, apply to ensure that the amount to be recovered will be the tax that ought to have been paid at the time, increased to maintain its value in present day terms.
That is a more effective and practical Government response to the promotion of tax avoidance than to attempt to ban advertising of the kind indulged in by Mr Clyne.
